name: Martin SCHULZ
text: I declare the session suspended on Wednesday, 2 December 2015, to be resumed.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Ladies and gentlemen! This weekend, there was a huge breakthrough in Paris that many did not think possible: a global, groundbreaking, forward-looking climate agreement has been agreed there! Global because for the first time all the countries of the world are taking part in the fight against climate change.  It is groundbreaking because all the states now recognise that we must remain well below two degrees of global warming, and they even want to try to limit the increase to a maximum of 1.5 degrees Celsius.  And it is a forward-looking agreement because we want to become a climate-neutral planet in the second half of the century. This means that we do not emit more greenhouse gas emissions than the earth can cope with. That is why Paris is certainly a turning point for the future of all of us. Above all, if we really implement the agreement that has now been rightly hailed. To do this, we need to change a lot – especially in the production of energy and in the consumption of energy.  A five-year monitoring mechanism was set up in Paris, which will give us feedback every five years on how we are moving forward and where we need to do more to achieve the objectives. The European Union must implement this agreement internally and externally and actually comply with the obligations of the agreement.  On behalf of the European Parliament, I would like to thank all those who have worked for years for the success of the Paris Conference. I would like to take this opportunity to thank you, Commissioner Arias Caete, on this day in this House for your work on this conference. We know that you worked intensively there! (Applause) However, I would also like to pass on this thanks to the Council. As we all know, the Luxembourg Minister for the Environment, Mrs Dieschbourg, has worked very closely with the Commission as President-in-Office of the Council.  I think I would like to thank the Executive Secretary, Mrs Figueres, but also the Secretary-General of the United Nations, Mr Ban Ki-moon. Ladies and gentlemen, the French Government, which hosted these events and organised the conference, has done a tremendous job. This morning, assuming your agreement, I conveyed the thanks and congratulations of the European Parliament to the President of the Climate Conference, the French Foreign Minister Laurent Fabius, in a personal conversation and invited him to present the results here in Parliament, if he so wishes. Mr Fabius has accepted the invitation and would like to address the results of the conference in January. Once again, ifellows from all the groups in this House who were present at the conference and who contributed to their success, I would like to express my sincere thanks and congratulations. (Applause)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The final draft agenda of this part-session, as set out in the Conference of Presidents at its meeting on Wednesday 9 December 2015 in accordance with Rule 149 of the Rules of Procedure, has been distributed. Before I come to the individual days of the agenda, I would like to make a brief procedural communication to the House in order to make a request to you again in connection with this procedural communication. This is the report by Mr Grébarczyk on the Energy Union. It is an own-initiative report. I have had a total of more than 200 amendments to this own-initiative report, requests for a separate vote or requests for a split vote – more than 200. I asked the ENF Group, which tabled the largest proportion of the amendments, to reconsider whether all these amendments really needed to be tabled, otherwise I would have rejected the amendment and asked the committee to revisit the amendments. Thankfully, the group has withdrawn a number of the amendments, so that we now have a total of 59 amendments, but still 40 amendments to a separate vote and 44 amendments to a split vote. According to our estimate, you will be voting on this own-initiative report for about 45 minutes on Tuesday. We reduced it from about an hour and ten minutes to 45 minutes. At every plenary session, I receive strong criticism from your ranks that the votes take too long. You are right! I would therefore ask you to think again intensively about whether every split vote, whether every separate vote must actually be the same, whether every roll-call vote is really so necessary. They would give themselves some relief. Despite the clear breach of the minimum quo, I have now refrained from referring this report back to committee. However, if we have 200 to 300 amendments to own-initiative reports, I will continue to ask the committees to look again at such an enormous number of amendments, otherwise we will significantly exceed the voting time in plenary. We now come to the work plan for this week. I have no amendments to the order of business.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The first item on the agenda is the joint debate on the road to a European Energy Union (2015/2113(INI)) (A8-0341/2015) and – the report by Peter Eriksson on behalf of the Committee on Industry, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and energy on achieving the 10% electricity interconnection target - preparing the European electricity grid for 2020 (2015/2108(INI)) (A8-0330/2015).

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: deputy rapporteur. – Mr President, Commissioner, as you know, my honourable colleague and friend Marek Gróbarczyk joined the new Polish Government as a minister and asked me to take over his report and help pass the plenary successfully.  Marek thanks the shadow rapporteurs for their constructive cooperation and balanced compromises. They also believe that the amendments tabled in plenary will not fundamentally upset the balance to date.  Of course, we are pleased that the Commission is working intensively on the Energy Union project, so three weeks ago we were already informed here in plenary about the progress in implementation. Opinions on what the details of the Energy Union should look like differ, as the last debate has shown. And many of the arguments will surely be repeated again today. I would like to address some important elements, particularly from the point of view of the rapporteur, Mark Gróbarczyk. The Energy Union is to be based on a robust common energy market. However, where necessary, market-based instruments should be supported by solidarity mechanisms with Member States now largely dependent on one energy supplier. And these mechanisms should be strengthened as part of the revision of legislation, e.g. the Gas Security of Supply Regulation. In this context, the report expresses concern about the planned doubling of the capacity of the Nord Stream pipeline and the possible negative effects on energy security, diversification of supply and the principle of solidarity between Member States. The report also highlights the need to ensure long-term energy supplies through Ukraine. The Commission must guarantee full compliance with European Union competition law and energy legislation, including the third energy package. This also applies to future intergovernmental agreements between Member States and third countries. If the Commission had assessed in advance the consistency of all forthcoming agreements with European Union legislation, we could have avoided some controversy. The decarbonisation of the European Union economy must be properly managed. It must not lead to higher energy prices, energy poverty, deindustrialisation of the European economy or an increase in unemployment. At the same time, the exclusive right of Member States to choose the energy mix must be honoured. Reducing CO2 emissions should be a key objective, but it is up to the Member States to achieve this target. And to do this, they need as much flexibility as possible. In this context, I would like to stress that we must also respect nuclear energy as a low-carbon energy source essential for a number of countries. The report rightly calls for its support here as well. When I mention the objectives of the European Union, I see, of course, the sensitive issue of energy efficiency. The report does not call for binding targets for the Member States and I believe that this compromise reached in the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy will be maintained. Today I will not go into the details of COP 21, because tomorrow afternoon the plenary conclusions of the conference are on the agenda. The issue of electricity interconnection is addressed in detail in mr Eriksson's report. I would just like to underline the strengthening of national networks in order to avoid energy overflows through neighbouring states. As regards gas, the Gróbarczyk report highlights, in addition to inter connectors, the importance of LNG infrastructure and natural gas storage facilities. My colleague Gróbarczyk's report is very comprehensive and there is no time to discuss it further. I will therefore save some time for my colleagues and thank the shadow rapporteurs once again for their cooperation.

name: Peter ERIKSSON
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I have to say, as the President said just now, that we have a global climate agreement at hand for the first time, and that is something that must strengthen all of us who have worked to find a solution to these difficult issues over the last ten to twenty years.  There is a process of revision and follow-up, and we have an agreement that says that we have a target that is well below two degrees. It is a great success. The question is what this means for the European Union. Yes, a few things are that we need to speed up the process of creating a common energy market and speeding up work on the Energy Union.  We need to remove subsidies on fossil fuels faster than we have imagined in the past. We also need to get a price on coal and ensure that we have a functioning ETS that is not yet working properly today, and we need to concentrate even more on energy efficiency in order to achieve the climate targets.  These are issues that come up in the Energy Union, but also part of my report that I have presented here and which deals with the interconnection of electricity networks in Europe. With common functioning electricity networks and a common market, we can achieve much of what we are striving for.  We can achieve cheaper electricity, cheaper electricity generation, cheaper electricity for consumers and businesses in Europe, and we can also have more renewable energy and more investment with a common functioning electricity market, and get more investment in renewable electricity where it is most efficient.  In places like the North Sea, we can get more wind energy produced. In Spain we can get more solar energy produced. With a larger interconnected electricity network and a common market, we can make this work together. The different renewable types of energy also tie each other together and balance each other in a better way. Then we can also more easily achieve the climate targets that we have now taken on. However, we can also achieve better competitiveness through cheaper electricity for European industry, and this is particularly important at a time when we still have very high unemployment in many countries. If we get rid of the energy islands that we still have in Europe, for example in Poland, in the United Kingdom, spain and the Iberian Peninsula, then it also makes a major contribution to strengthening competitiveness and European industry.  I think one goal is not enough for the future. We need to add regional targets to remove the bottlenecks in the electricity networks and we also need to strengthen the supervisory authority ACER with better budgets, more staff and better opportunities to exercise its supervision and control.  Finally, we also need to make greater efforts to introduce the best available technology BAT (Best Available Technology) when we invest and invest in new electricity grids. This means that we reduce conflicts in the area with the local population and can have investments carried out more quickly.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, let me begin by thanking the rapporteurs - Mr Eriksson, Mr Gróbarczyk and Mr To-enovsk - and all the Members involved in these two draft reports.  Both projects certainly have a balanced and inclusive approach and underline the need for the Energy Union to be ambitious in its five dimensions, to make its progress verifiable and quantifiable and for this process to be transparent.  The Commission fully agrees with these three elements, as already illustrated by the report on the State of the Energy Union adopted by the College a month ago and which was presented to this House by Vice-President Eef-Soviet, who has been encouraging and coordinating our action in this important priority for the European Union. I would like to focus my speech on these three issues.  Firstly, the need to maintain the energy union's levels of ambition. I have just returned from Paris, where over the past two weeks the European Union, with its allies, has led the negotiations to reach the most ambitious climate agreement in history.  But the implementation of that agreement begins from today. That means we have to meet our goal of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 40% from 1990 levels; we need to achieve a 27% share of renewable energy and improve energy efficiency by 27% by 2030 with a 30% view.  As far as renewable energy is concerned, we already have a 15% share in the European Union, but we need to increase our efforts to make the 2030 target a reality. And that is why we will have to address the revision of the Renewable Energy Directive scheduled for the second half of 2016.  As regards energy efficiency, let me reiterate that the Commission is already considering how we could increase the target to 30%, as requested by this draft report. The Energy Efficiency Directive is also the worst being implemented. That is why we will have to make sure that it is fulfilled in all Member States.  But we also need to increase our level of ambition. That is why, next year, I will present a set of proposals related to energy efficiency in sectors such as heating and cooling, buildings and transport and industry emissions.  In addition, I believe that a transition to a low-carbon economy should be guided by innovation and the European Strategic Energy Technology Plan will be critical.  The second issue I want to talk about today is the need to measure our progress, which is linked to the Eriksson report on the 10% electricity interconnection target by 2020. Today, only twenty Member States achieve these objectives and for some, such as the Iberian Peninsula, the Baltic States or Cyprus, electrical interconnection is clearly insufficient. In addition, lack of interconnection is an impediment to ensuring the integration of renewable energy into our energy matrix and achieving higher competitiveness quotas. We will start in 2015 with an inauguration and a new electrical interconnection through the Pyrenees, and today we have inaugurated the new electrical interconnections between Lithuania and Poland, and between Lithuania and Sweden. Both LitPolLink and NordBalt will be key to ending the energy isolation of the Baltic States.  And we have just adopted a second list of projects of common interest containing the most important interconnection priorities for the European Union: 108 electricity projects that will enable twenty-six Member States to achieve the 10% interconnection target by 2020.  But going back to the draft report we are discussing today, I am particularly pleased with the ambition it shows by including the longer-term target of 15% by 2030.  I announce that I will propose the establishment of a group of energy infrastructure experts to monitor progress in the 10% target and make proposals if the target is not met, as well as to advise the Commission on how to achieve the 15% target.  One of the central pillars of next year's legislative proposals will be the design of the electricity market for greater market integration.  Strengthening ACER's role and promoting closer regional cooperation, as indicated in the draft report, will be key features of market design proposals, and that will be of cardinal importance for energy security.  As the draft Gróbarczyk report highlights, we have made significant progress in diversifying gas sources and gas routes.  The next package on security of supply, which includes a review of the gas supply safety regulation and a proposal to review the decision on intergovernmental agreements will help us go further. And that's important because many countries rely heavily on Russian gas imports.  And on that issue, let me respond to the concerns about NordStream 2 raised in the draft report.  First of all, I have to say that it is clear that this project, like any other, will have to fully respect European Union law. Secondly, I would like to stress that the Commission will support only those projects which are in line with the objectives of the Energy Union, including energy security. And, in this context, diversification of supply sources, routes and suppliers is key.  Finally, I would like to clarify that the European Union continues to see Ukraine as a safe and necessary transit country. I will make sure Parliament is informed of any developments.  And in this spirit I address my last point: the need to be held accountable. The State of the Energy Union made it clear that the Energy Union can only function if it is based on a reliable and transparent process anchored in the legislation.  Over the next few years, we will propose a number of legislative proposals on the five dimensions. And here Parliament, as co-legislator, will play a decisive role.  In addition to this, of course, we need a robust governance process, as highlighted in the draft report on the Energy Union. As many of you have pointed out, this process would not make sense if it became a mere bureaucratic process. That is why next year we will propose an initiative on simplifying planning and reporting so that, after 2020, Member States will develop an integrated national energy and climate plan; that the monitoring system should be based on a report on the progress made by Member States; and for the Commission to assess collective progress in an annual comprehensive state of the European Union.  In this context, the powers of this Parliament will be fully respected. Ladies and gentlemen, let me conclude by saying that the Commission welcomes these two draft reports. We will ensure that the Energy Union remains an ambitious, responsible and measurable project.  He doesn't expect hard work. Next year will be decisive by the large number of concrete initiatives included in the legislative programme for 2016. I will work with this Parliament to make the Energy Union a reality.

name: Ana GOMES
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, Human Rights, Common Security and Defence Policy. – Mr President, the European Union really needs to have an ambitious strategy and that means having an action plan with benchmarks and governance, and then the Commission's role is, in fact, irreplaceable. We need an energy union because it is strategic for our independence and also to promote the independence of other states with whom we relate and to avoid conflicts in the world, as we have seen both in the Middle East and in the Russia-Ukraine conflict. We absolutely need to focus on the interconnectivity of energy networks – the Commissioner said how ridiculous it is, for example, that the Iberian Peninsula does not even guarantee it in terms of electricity. We need to focus on energy efficiency. We need more investment from the Member States and the Commission in renewable energy, not nuclear, from my point of view.  This is because there are strategic opportunities for the competitiveness of European companies in this area as well. It is the only way to be consistent with the commitments made under COP 21.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. – Mr President, first of all, congratulations and thanks to all the Negotiators of the European Union, Commissioner Cañete and the host country, France, for the climate agreement reached in Paris this weekend. It is a very important step globally. Transport will play an important role in reducing emissions, and the Committee on Transport wants to draw attention to this in its own Opinion on the Energy Union. Thirty per cent of Europe's energy is spent on transport in particular, and transport is highly dependent on fossil sources. The committee considers it important that we promote energy efficiency and renewable energy sources in a very technology-neutral way throughout Europe. We know that it is already possible to use renewable fuels in air transport, and the Committee on Transport encourages Europe to open up the market to renewable fuels in air transport in Europe.

name: András GYÜRK
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. The European People's Party is committed to creating an Energy Union for the benefit of European citizens. The report we are discussing today provides a balanced summary of the steps that can bring us closer to a European energy policy for consumers.  Our decision tomorrow could be a clear path. Our aim is to strengthen security of supply and increase energy efficiency at an affordable price. This requires, where necessary, the building of new infrastructure, further unifying the market and forcing the application of legislation.  At the end of the road, we hope, is a Europe capable of increasing its competitiveness on the international stage. A Europe in which new jobs are created, for example through technological research and development, the promotion of innovations or, for example, investments in energy efficiency. This journey will be a long one, there is a lot of work to be done here in Parliament, and in order to walk the road, we legislators must always be ready to compromise. A good example of this is the report under discussion.  On the one issue, I particularly welcome the compromise on the extraction of mineral resources within Europe's borders. I am glad that we agree that it is not parliament's responsibility to decide what is economical, what is not, what has potential and what does not. That will be decided by the players in the economy. Our task is to establish an appropriate regulatory framework and to demand strict climate, health and environmental standards.  Finally, I trust that, as a result of constructive cooperation, Tomorrow Parliament will be able to send its message on the importance of the Energy Union to European citizens.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are at last here, on behalf of the Group of the Party of European People's Party(S&D).  This Parliament is saying its opinion on the Energy Union, that is to say on the most ambitious strategy for the integration of European energy markets since that first courageous and somewhat visionary project: the European Coal and Steel Community. Well, more than sixty years after the context and the world have changed a great deal, but the issue always remains the same: guaranteeing the energy security of the Member States, as a factor of stability, competitiveness and growth of their territories, with an additional challenge, the capital challenge, that of climate and sustainable development. It is therefore in this spirit that we are going to vote, after weeks and months of negotiations, on the basis of a solid text to which almost all the groups have contributed and which place this House at the centre of the debate on the future of the Energy Union. I believe that there are two main points: the call for strong governance, with full ownership of Parliament in the ordinary legislative procedure and essential objectives – the second point – that we Socialists and Democrats, together with others, want even more ambitious in terms of efficiency so that the energy transition is courageous and socially sustainable.  Parliament is therefore returning to the field, ready to make its voice heard on the dense path of building the Energy Union, with the commitment shown in recent months by the Commission in ferrying the Energy Union stage by stage and the obstinacy of this House in seeking broad understandings of the basic objectives, as conditions for important results, towards a single, harmonious and fair European energy area. All this is finally there, it is of course up to us to continue the work.

name: Ian DUNCAN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Arias Cañete, whose resemblance to Father Christmas has not gone amiss here today. Mr Arias Cañete, you are bringing to us gifts from Paris and I think that should be in the forefront of all our minds.  What we have seen in Paris is perhaps more important because of the ambition it represents: 1.5°C  as an ambition is significant. What does it mean for us now? We must do some of the underpinning research and understand the implications for all our policies; not just those on the Union, but across every single one of our targets. We need to look at what that ambition can represent and should represent. I should pay tribute to my colleague, Mr Gróbarczyk, who has gone back to Poland to work on fisheries, the poor bugger. It will be more difficult working on fisheries than energy, I suspect. The reality, however, is that the Energy Union must be the beating heart of the European continent. If it is, we can make significant progress. Right now, by combining each of our states’ ambitions we can interlink and we can make that difference happen. Interconnectivity is important and we must make sure that it actually works. I believe the North Sea is a place where we can see that ambition in reality and I will push again, Mr Arias Cañete, for you to realise that the North Sea is good to go and ready to go. Let us interlink that basin and let us see that progress in reality. Let it be a beacon for the rest of the EU so that we can make some substantial progress. I think that should be our next, and perhaps most important step. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: blue-card question. – Mr Duncan, I agree with you on the North Sea, so do you agree with me on the key role which binding targets play in ensuring certainty for investors in renewables, energy efficiency and cleantech? A binding energy efficiency target would create jobs, reduce energy poverty and create benefits for our economy – all with one swift act. Without them, are we sending the right signals to investors?

name: Ian DUNCAN
text: blue-card answer. – Miss Kirton-Darling, I do not believe that binding anything is actually going to be the driver. It is actually realising these things that will make the significant difference. I believe right now that those commitments are sound and solid, just as they have been in Paris. What we witnessed was a binding agreement in part and a voluntary agreement in other parts, but that does not lessen the ambition. It should not lessen the output either.

name: Morten PETERSEN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first let me thank the rapporteur and the other shadows for their hard work and good cooperation on this Energy Union file. I would personally gladly have seen even more emphasis on the role of energy efficiency and renewables in the future European energy mix, but I find that we have ended up with a constructive text which has, in most respects, found the right balance between pragmatism and ambition. On governance, a clear emphasis should be given to Parliament’s role in this process and the need for Member States’ progress on implementation to be carefully scrutinised. I am also happy that we have laid the groundwork for taking a more holistic and, in my view, ambitious approach to the integration of energy systems and solutions. Particularly on heating and cooling, we have emphasised the important role of integrating technologies and solutions to find the most efficient way of keeping warm or keeping cool. This is absolutely crucial in the context of our common energy security and solidarity.  Finally, I would like to remind colleagues here today of how far we have come and how important our role as Parliamentarians is in this debate.  If we are to play a role in the future governance, we have to demonstrate also that we can act responsibly and work with the common good in mind. I very much hope that we together, in this European Parliament, are able to adopt this crucial report tomorrow.  (The speaker agreed to take two blue-card questions under Rule 162(8))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Dear colleague, you have given the rating "thank fulg" to this report. Of course, it is important to have energy efficiency, balance the mix and reduce global warming. I'd be interested to know why you rated "thank fulging." Have you thought, perhaps, that there are concrete situations in Europe where it will not be possible to balance the mix, where deindustrialisation will be done, where certain investments will be closed, for example for fossil fuels? Or what's the reason you rated "thankful"?

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. - Mr President, Honourable Member, I would like to thank you for your support. I would have liked to have asked you something quite similar, but I will also be a little more specific: on the energy mix, I would be very curious if you would tell me what your group, your group, thinks about nuclear energy within this energy mix, especially given that some Member States have a flexible interpretation of the Energy Union and would not want to compromise in this regard.

name: Morten PETERSEN
text: blue-card answer. – Let me address the last question first because it all relates to the energy mix. When it comes to nuclear, we had a free vote within the ALDE Group on this specific issue.  This also relates somewhat to the first question on efficiency and renewables, because it is clearly stated – and it is a prerogative of all the work we have been doing here over the past year or year and a half – that the energy mix is a sovereign decision for Member States. Now we can regret this, either of us, but these are the hard facts. These are the political realities with which we have to work, and based upon this reality I think that we have actually achieved quite a good result with this text on the table right now.  I would personally have preferred even more emphasis on efficiency and on renewables, but at the same time clearly acknowledging what other Groups and groupings have meant and have taken as a position on this. All this is to say that, with all these conditions on the table, I think we have managed to reach quite a satisfactory outcome. I hope it will be passed tomorrow.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, the energy union strategy will have a decisive impact on people's lives. That is why we have a responsibility not to adopt as Parliament's positions the negative policies and incomplete proposals promoted by the Commission. It is not enough to say that unemployment and poverty must be combated. We must support a development social policy that ensures energy as a public social good, to which we will all have equal access. To achieve this, we must ensure that energy remains outside the TTIP agreement and that the Commission is not given powers at the expense of the sovereign rights of states.  We must then stop talking vaguely about removing the energy isolation of states and promote investment in interconnections and public infrastructure of strategic importance, for the benefit of the people. Equally important is to stop simply noting how domestic energy sources should be exploited and to support, inter alia, the creation of a Mediterranean gas hub in the Mediterranean, with the potential to develop LNG. Finally, we must stop funding nuclear energy and promote a realistic integrated strategy to implement the 2020 and 2030 renewable energy targets. In this respect, I believe that the amendments we have tabled as a group of the European United Left, the Northern Green Left, are heading. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Sylikiotis, I would like to thank Mr Sylikiotis for his work on this In your view, would it have been necessary to highlight the eastern Mediterranean in the Eriksson report on the achievement of the 10% electricity interconnection target and to highlight this area in particular, particularly with a view to increasing diversification in the area of Europe's energy security?

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), "blue card" answer. – I want to say that there should indeed be a reference to the Eastern Mediterranean, because important gas deposits have been discovered in the Eastern Mediterranean and there is a Member State there, Cyprus. We believe that it is important to strengthen the energy security of Europe and especially of Southern and South-Eastern Europe, which currently faces too many problems, to accurately record these important deposits, and that is why we believe that the report should also focus on this region.

name: Claude TURMES
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the I do not know whether the Commissioner is a Santa Claus or a wiseman from the Tres Reyes. In any case, however, he did a good job in Paris with the Luxembourg Minister for the Environment, and I would therefore like to thank him. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which The report we are voting on tomorrow shows a certain discrepancy with the spirit of departure that prevailed in Paris. If we want to move forward with the Energy Union, we either argue all the time about things like coal, nuclear, shale gas, or we are trying together to agree on five no regrets. Energy efficiency: we should go further. And, Commissioner, perhaps you can say something about this afterwards: it is important that the Commission's models 27, 30, 33, 35, but also 40% energy efficiency are knocked off for jobs in Europe, reductions in energy imports, competitiveness and climate protection. The second, renewable energy: right, the spirit of departure in Paris, more than 100 multinational companies that are in favour of 100% renewable energy. In 2030, there must be no brake block towards 100% renewable energy, but a lever in this direction. Thirdly, smart grids. My colleague Peter Eriksson has described this well for the higher-level networks, but we also need it at the distribution level. Fourthly, functioning markets: ETS is not working as well as it has been in the past, nor is the energy markets. We still have to work on this next year. Fifthly, we need a common external energy policy, 29 votes that negotiate in one direction. And the doubling of the Nord Stream gas pipeline is not constructive and must be withdrawn. Mrs Merkel and Mr Hollande should finally understand this. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Blue card question. - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Congressman, I'm sorry. You mentioned shale gas, coal and nuclear energy together in your speech. Do you think they are on an equal footing with decarbonisation? Because it's always there, as a trigger, it's just renewable energies. So my question is, do you treat the use of nuclear energy, which a country intends to use, at the same level as coal? Don't you consider it clean energy in any way?

name: Claude TURMES
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Unfortunately, you were not in Paris last week. Otherwise, you would know that large solar plants now cost half of new nuclear power plants. And with that, this discussion has all but been resolved, including in Europe. Coal is a no-go - we have to get out of there. We must, of course, also see how we meet Poland. We need a strategy for Poland to help Poland move more towards efficiency and renewable energy. Shale gas: If I may say so, inject tons of chemicals into the earth and then hope that drinking water will not be destroyed, that's really not a good idea.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there are certainly many parts in this report that we can support, but while we in Europe are still discussing non-binding and uns ambitious targets, Morocco, according to the Financial Times, is already close to reaching 42% renewable energy in 2020, more than twice as high as the European Union, and has set itself the target of 50% by 2030.  The Eu ropean Union should also learn from Uruguay, which in 2015 has already reached 94% renewables with a legislative framework that gave certainty to investors. The report on which we will be voting tomorrow also contains a scandalous phrase to say the least: 'nuclear energy should be supported in any form by EU funding mechanisms or EU financial institutions'. A nice pay really. In Britain, the Hinkley Point nuclear power station will perhaps only be built because the government will pay twice the market price for 27 years. We believe that nuclear choices cannot be at the discretion of the Member States, because they jeopardise the safety of the citizens of neighbouring countries and of the whole of the European continent. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. Thank you for accepting my blue card. You mentioned renewables and cooperation with neighbouring countries. My question is, do you agree with me that more potential has to be used by the Countries of the Western Balkans? Hydro-powered hydropower, and as an example I mention the fact that your country Italy from Montenegro will get electricity through an underwater channel on the Adriatic. So, do you support the western Balkan countries getting involved in this common policy in some way?

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: Answer to a blue card question. I believe that electricity interconnections between countries, including by adopting the latest technologies, should be encouraged. As far as hydroelectric power is concerned, for many parts of Europe we are now at the saturation of what is sustainable when it comes to protecting the natural situation. Let us remember, however, that hydroelectric power can have problems as a result of climatic changes, which in any case put the same supply of hydroelectric basins at risk. However, we must also take account of this variable, which will become increasingly serious in the years to come.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has The Paris Climate Agreement provides for a well-below two-degree global warming and to achieve greenhouse gas neutrality by 2050. The Europeans have made a binding commitment to this, and many other countries are not.  The report on the Energy Union under discussion today is of great importance because, through the mix of measures it sets out, it enables many Member States to achieve these reduction targets or to move closer to these reduction targets. In essence, this is about measures to reduce CO2 emissions, increase the share of renewable energy in the energy mix and improve energy efficiency, primarily of buildings and transport, and the TRAN Committee was therefore involved.  It is therefore a question of reversing the trend in energy policy: moving away from fossil fuels and nuclear energy, away from centralised market models and dirty generation technologies, towards a sustainable, resource-efficient economy, more competition and greater consumer involvement.  How do we want to achieve this? By increasing energy supply – certainly, as has already been mentioned today – greater diversification, more energy diplomacy and better cooperation in the field of electricity supply. By developing energy infrastructure – as Mr Eriksson's report shows today – in particular, network expansion to increase interconnectivity – 10% by 2020, 15% by 2030 – the development of networks and decentralised generation and new storage facilities, as well as more funding for research and development, innovation in the energy sector.  The strategic focus is on lowering energy prices, creating decentralized feed-in opportunities, creating greater energy security – i.e. reducing the risk of blackout – and creating a better funding opportunity for new technologies and green jobs.  But it is to be kept to the fore, especially with regard to COP 21 and the commitments of the EU Member States. Our greatest concern must be to maintain the attractiveness and competitiveness of the site, which is in line with a healthy and sustainable climate policy.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. In my opinion, this is a good report, and we will vote on it tomorrow. However, let me draw your attention and the attention of our constituents to the fact that this is nothing more than a theory on which we will legislate. What will be the practical implementation, we do not yet know, we do not see.  And it is not by chance that I draw attention to the importance of the practical implementation of this law, together with the enforcement of the law, because I could come up with rather bad examples, and I will come up with one that affected my country when Hungary announced his plan for the renovation and reconstruction of the Paks nuclear power plant, which met considerable opposition from the European Commission. I really hope that this will not work this way any longer. I would also like to draw attention to another very important thing: if we are really serious about this and we legislate on this subject tomorrow on the Energy Union, I am sure that compromise solutions will be in place, which means that it will not be the European Commission, not Brussels, who will tell the Member States what their tasks are, what they can and cannot do in the field of energy. , but they will be able to choose it independently and independently, of course in cooperation with the Commission. To do this, I wish everyone a good job!

name: Bendt BENDTSEN
text: Mr President! Europe urgently needs an energy union and urgently needs a single market for electricity. Better interconnectors are a prerequisite for both energy union and a single market for electricity. The Eriksson report is a good contribution to focusing on a target of at least 10% interconnectors and, of course, it must be seen in close conjunction with the report on the Energy Union.  I would like to thank Mr Saunders. I would also like to thank Mr Eriksson for bringing together a broad majority in Parliament for the report, but also to my colleagues in the EPP Group for their firm support for the report. Better interconnting will mean better security of supply and cheaper consumer electricity prices for our citizens and for our businesses in Europe. With lower electricity prices, our businesses become more competitive, and that is what we need: to create growth and create jobs in Europe. Too many young people in southern Europe are without jobs today, which is why we need to increase competitiveness so that we can also compete on the world market.  On top of the COP21 in Paris, which I of course very much welcome, I would also like to thank Mr Cop21 in Paris. Mr Cañete and the negotiating team here from the European Union, which has asserted its influence. There is no doubt that action must be taken now, and I believe that we now at least have a good objective in order to achieve what we want to achieve. This also means that if we are to achieve those objectives, we must look more at energy efficiency. We need to look more at creating a single energy market with more inter-connectivity, and it is not just a question of getting more interconnention, it is also a question of getting quality, so that it is also exploited where it is available and that there are no national interests and blocking electricity from going from the south to the north. , north to south, west to east and east to west. So, all in all, thank you to Mr Saunders. I would like to take mr Eriksson for a good report, which we look forward to being adopted. (The speaker agrees to answer a blue card question in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Milan ZVER
text: A question raised by raising a blue card. – Thank you very much, Mr Bentsen, for accepting the question. I would like to say this: I agree with everything you have said. However, it seems to me that we are still a long way from the European Union, that the energy vulnerability of Europe, which should join forces, is rather shared by European countries or members. Do you think it is better to build a community concept, an energy community, instead of a European Union concept? Instead of the concept of an energy union, are we building the concept of an energy community?

name: Bendt BENDTSEN
text: Blue-card response. Mr President! I believe that the plan for an energy union in Europe is the right way to go. I believe, of course, that the energy mix that exists in the various countries should remain free. I believe that more energy efficiency is needed, and I would also like us to be more ambitious in this area than it seems.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, we are facing one of the perhaps most important debates in this parliamentary term: the debate on the Energy Union. It is because it is important to combat the energy dependence that larstrastras our economy; it is because it is important to combat climate change by boosting renewable energy; and it is because we need to democratize energy and make it reach consumers at an affordable price. This requires making more Of Europe, ensuring the minimum 10% interconnection, and ending the energy islands. This is reflected in the Council Conclusions, the Commission Communication and the position of the European Parliament; even the Treaty itself reflects the necessary solidarity that must be in the Union's energy policy.  Therefore, all these agencies call for all necessary efforts to achieve this necessary 10%. In that regard, I would have liked the Eriksson report to have been perhaps clearer, with a closer defence of that 10%. Because I think it not only does not defend, but questions, 15%, and introduces the necessary scientific and technical assessment of this 10%.  In this regard, I would like to recall and stress that this is a political and non-scientific or technical objective. That is why I would have liked a much clearer strategy to end these energy islands that are so necessary to this day.  This contrasts with the report on 'Towards a European Energy Union', which sets out a clear defence of this 10% minimum; I also believe that this report, although it contains aspects which the Socialist Group of course cannot share, is a good report in the sense that it contains many other proposals which I consider innovative and important, such as support for the self-consumption of renewables and consumer prominence in energy management.  In short, in order to achieve greater consistency, I call for the support of the three amendments contained in the texts of the Commission, the Council and the European Parliament in this regard.  (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Peter ERIKSSON
text: question ("blue card"). My answer to you is that I really think we are in agreement. I want us to use the 10% target and that it is important, but I also think that there are other regional supplementary targets that are also important if we are to have a functioning common electricity market, which, for example, in some countries is needed to strengthen the electricity grid, but also between some countries that already have other problems. So in order to remove bottlenecks and have a common electricity market, additional targets are also needed, not just the 10% target.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: , 'blue card' response. – Mr Eriksson, I just want to tell you that, as you said, it is not incompatible at all. The defence of regional objectives is not incompatible with the priority and first need which is the defence of that minimum 10% interconnection needed to wipe out the energy islands. Therefore, we agree.  What I have said is simply that I would have liked a closer defence of that minimum 10% needed to wipe out those three energy islands that we have in the European Union at the moment, because if it is not that way, we will not end them - as you know very well – in view of the progression and the figures at our we have.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I was in Kyoto 15 years ago with then Environment Minister Merkel and have followed all the climate summits since then, but I have rarely seen an event where there has been so much self-congratulation by politicians as this one. I think a little more modesty would have been appropriate. Let us not forget that the 2-degree target is a non-binding goal. I suspect it will suffer the same fate as similar goals. Remember: 0.7% development aid, 3% for research and development? All these goals have been missed. There is also no reference to a market-based instrument. Finally, I fear that Europe will remain an expensive energy island and continue to export jobs, growth and prosperity. Incidentally , and here comes my ceterum censeo – I believe that the euro must be abolished as a single currency.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Mr President, just one remark on the Energy Union report, Mr Gróbarczyk’s report. I think it is a balanced report. I also like the emphasis on Nord Stream 2, a project which I find is being settled in a way that is not compatible with the Energy Union.  As a shadow rapporteur on the Eriksson report, I think we have got a good report. I think that this is a report which really fits in with the Energy Union objective. It is very concrete and it is a key issue in terms of interconnectivity. I think that it is sufficiently ambitious. I think that the regional aspect is also well founded.  I believe that we need to reflect of course on the ‘energy islands’ that we have referred to, but also on what the market flows are. I think that the Eriksson report combines these two views, these two elements very well indeed. And of course the ambitions are there and will be there for the future.  But beyond that, we need to base the 10 % target on concrete impact assessments; and that is also in the report. That is why I would welcome that we vote firmly in favour.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Eriksson. We think its report is a good one, and I want to make it clear, in contrast to the energy union report, which, in my view, comes from a deep past and does not meet the current requirements in any way. We support long-term EU targets to combat climate change and renewable energy expansion targets, which must also be binding, nationally, At European and also regionally. To return to the electricity interconnection targets, we believe that these targets must not be static. They are reasonable if they actually fill gaps, if they help to fill supply gaps, and they are reasonable when they also serve to develop decentralised renewable energies. In this combination, we think that's good and right. I would like to ask you the question: how far will we actually get in all this discussion if subsidies are actually abolished in the expansion of the European electricity network and at the same time in Spain for solar and solar power, if in Germany the new tendering system for renewable energies is so that no small players can play along here, but only the big ones can get to these things. , when, for example, energy cooperatives hardly play a role? We believe that there must be room for large and small players in order to maintain the acceptance of renewable energy among citizens, not limited to the need for such cooperatives to be self-empowering and to provide decentralised electricity generation – on the ground and among the people.

name: David COBURN
text: – Mr President, the Commission plans to revise the Emissions Trading Scheme and its allowance system. The EU claims this will distribute available allowances more efficiently. We in UKIP are against the proposal as we reject the damaging EU ETS system and this revision of it. We believe that the Commission should recognise that the entire EU project has failed, causing higher energy prices in all Member States. It has caused job losses, plant closures and a massive outflow of industry and investment to outside-EU areas – especially in my constituency of Scotland, where it has destroyed our steel industry. This House has spent too much of its time trying to fix this failing mechanism and its devastating effects on energy prices, the industry of Europe and industrial competitiveness in general. It is time to put our people first: out of the EU, out of this nonsense!  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Claude TURMES
text: blue-card question. – I think that you are talking a lot of nonsense here, especially when you blame Europe for the high energy prices in the UK. So listen now, because I will state the facts. Prices in the UK today are EUR 55 per megawatt hour; prices in Scandinavia are EUR 25 per megawatt hour today. Scandinavia has five, six, eight times more renewables and more climate policy than the UK, so if there is anybody to blame for the high prices, it is London, not Brussels.

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card answer. – Well sir, we know you are a Green and in my country we have had our country polluted with useless German windmills and propellers all over our landscape. They do not provide energy at affordable prices and they ruin the landscape. We want things that work, not things that do not work. We want to see industry and jobs in our country. You may want to go back to the Dark Ages, sir, but not every one of us wants to live in a cave.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Mr President, with regard to the report by Marek Grebarczyk, who is also a friend, I would like to say that there are many positive elements, but also a number of negative ones. It puts states at the centre of the strategy. I believe that, in fact, you can only achieve energy resilience if you rely on the links that are the states. Without the states, no energy policy is possible. In my opinion, Mr Grebarczyk is wrong to abandon sustainable development because we have, as Mr Turmes pointed out, energy prices that allow new energies to be competitive. It is also wrong not to rely on Russia and, on the contrary, to want to circumvent it. I wonder if it is more reliable to rely on Turkey, which would bypass Russia, knowing that it is a partner that funds terrorism and is against our civilizations. Another problem is that it gives too much power to the Commission. It defends a liberal ideology and, as a result, is not in a position to ensure energy security since its price vision does not support the market in the long term. This liberal view of prices leads to a total contradiction because you are asking for both lower prices and additional investment. One wonders how we will finance additional investments with prices that do not ensure their profitability. The Commission must not have bargaining power. We call on the Commission to stick to its role because, soon, it will be abolished by the rejection of England or by Germany which rightly defends its food security. I therefore beg the Commission to preserve the interests of the European Union and to stop pursuing a policy contrary to them.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: "I feel like I'm in Moscow in the 1970s at the Comecon Conference of the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance, where instead of relying on private companies, there are bureaucratic state incons and outs. And that's about ten percent, and why not nine or eleven koma three. You can immediately see that this is some kind of artificial border.
