We must insist that, if Ukraine wants to receive money, it is to ensure the security of the transmission lines that run through its territory. (The speaker agreed to answer the question raised by raising the "blue card" (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Peter ERIKSSON
text: blue-card question. – I would like to emphasise one thing that is important in this debate. The criticism often comes from countries like Poland and the United Kingdom. However, when we look at electricity prices in Europe, the countries that have the highest prices are Britain and Poland – and also Spain sometimes. This is because they are energy islands. The countries that have good connections with the other countries around have low prices and better competition for their industry.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. "Yes, of course, we want as many connections as possible, so that there is a market, so that energy can flow through all possible channels – and that is simple. It is just that the State does not regulate this market with various artificial requirements and blocking restrictions. That's it.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: Mr President, our European energy market is gradually being established. Commissioner, I listened to you well earlier and I understood that we were going to have a lot of work in 2016 on renewable energy or energy efficiency. On this point, I believe that there is much to be done and that there is an urgent need to work on it. I will focus on the energy market. In order for it to provide us with a high security of supply, I think we really need to work on interconnections. We have, of course, existing interconnections. They need to be strengthened and used to the maximum of their capacity, but that is not the only solution; nor is the only solution to develop more and more infrastructure. It is important to evaluate each new project very rigorously, to examine its feasibility and also to take into account future developments so as not to hinder projects that might be promising. It is also important that we have cost-benefit analyses to compare the different projects. The second solution is to ensure that investors benefit from a favourable framework for sustainable investment and more long-term contracts in the electricity market in order to secure and encourage investments, particularly in favour of renewable energy, which have very high fixed costs. This will also benefit users, especially the electro-intensive sectors, which are always demanding more predictability. This will provide a dynamic space for energy exchanges for the benefit of energy producers, network managers and consumers alike.

name: Dan NICA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, tonight's debate and tomorrow's votes are extremely important in defining the energy union framework. The two initiative reports, 'Towards a European Energy Union' and 'Achieving the 10% Electricity Interconnection Goal', present important elements for creating a safer, sustainable and competitive energy market. Proposed measures, such as the creation of a modernisation fund, additional consumer protection measures, support for regional cooperation projects between electricity and gas distribution system operators are important objectives. At the same time, given that small and medium-sized enterprises and European industry are vital to the European Union's economy and competitiveness, we must ensure that the proposed objectives and targets will not be met to the detriment of European industry and jobs. It is the Member States that need to set their own energy mix, with the achievement of all the targets for reducing carbon dioxide emissions, energy efficiency and renewable energies. We are concerned that there are Member States that are far from meeting their 2020 targets. Given the current context regarding our energy dependence on certain external factors, the achievement of a fully integrated internal market, security of supply, energy efficiency and the optimal use of the European Union's energy resources, as well as research and innovation, would maximise the benefits for new industries and new technologies, while ensuring protection and support for traditional labour and industries. In view of the role of interconnectivity in the completion of the Internal Market of the European Union, I stress the importance of the 10% electricity interconnection target, for which it is necessary to urgently mobilise all efforts at all levels and mobilise financial resources. The future post-2020 governance framework for the Energy Union must be ambitious, reliable, transparent, democratic, so that all legislative proposals within the Energy Union will have to be subject to the ordinary legislative procedure, which requires full involvement of Parliament's institution.

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: I have four reservations about the dossiers we are discussing today. Without a doubt, we must indeed focus on renewable energy. But the more renewable energy we produce, the more we burden the existing grids with peaks and troughs in supply. In order to neutralise this, we need better connections between member states.  Secondly, if we want to give renewable energy fair opportunities, we must let the market do its job as quickly as possible. And, for example, do not allow them to be falsified by the fact that Member States are going to allow subsidies on one particular technology.  A third concern: a greater supply of renewable energy also means that the consumer consumption pattern will have to be adjusted because of the unstable supply.  Fourth and final consideration: if we are to achieve the 2020 and 2030 targets and the subsequent targets, we need energy storage.  Conclusion: renewable energy is needed, but we must not be blind to the unforeseen costs involved.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I would like to begin by giving the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteur recognition for their solid work. However, the Energy Union is a major legislative project and therefore there is a risk that we will sometimes forget some of the decisions we have taken in the past. For this reason, I would like to supplement the list of five intelligent things that Mr Turmes came up with.  In addition to intelligent networks and markets and an intelligent foreign policy, we also need intelligent politicians, and for that reason it is worth remembering what we decided in connection with the ELUC file. In this context, we did not pull the rug away for ground-based and soil-based second-generation fuels. Now in paragraph 122 there is a little bad wording where we actually say that we are banning or want to ban all terrestrial biofuels, and that is, of course, a mistake, but, as Mr Cañete said, we need a good and robust process.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: – Modern economies run on CO2-free nuclear energy, on oil or gas or coal. Because industrial societies demand energy, and they did before the European Union existed. The EU's energy policy is based on Article 194(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, and it states - very sensibly - that the Member States themselves are concerned with their energy supply.  After all, no one knows what is needed better than those countries themselves, because they have years of experience in this, and the Treaty is clear in this. It is explicitly stipulated that the European Union must not interfere in the exploitation of a Member State's energy sources, including the choice of a Member State's energy sources, nor the structure of its energy supply. However, the European Commission has come up with plans for a joint energy union, which must focus on poverty reduction and climate change in addition to energy. But it is therefore concerned with the fight against sovereignty, because members present, a limited choice is not a free choice and that free choice is guaranteed in the Treaty. And with that, this plan is contrary to that treaty.  So we now have governments that no longer abide by their own laws, and i think that is a bad thing. Almost even worse is the enthusiasm with which the European Parliament embraces this plan. Doesn't anyone here realize that this plan is illegal? Of course you are aware of this, but the European Parliament has found a new toy with this, and that may cost some, the rule of law for example.

name: Jerzy BUZEK
text: – Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Thank you very much for the development of the Energy Union project. It is absolutely crucial for the energy security of Europeans and for the well-being of citizens. In Parliament, for five years now, we have called for this many times under the name of the European Energy Community. Now we are talking about this as an Energy Union. It is important that we continue in Parliament as we have had an impact on what is happening for these five years. That's why managing this project is so important. The European Commission and the European Parliament. Management. Key point. So that it is not open coordination.  The second point. Let us build an Energy Union of 36 countries, not 28. The Western Balkans, Ukraine and Moldova are implementing EU law. They are our close neighbours. They can help us and we can help them. Typical win-win situation. Finally, it is important that we pay attention to electricity, because we have made progress in gas. The reverse flow, new cross-border connections in the gas have given a big leap forward. There's no electricity in it yet.  And one last thing. The Energy Union produces and sets standards. It defines what needs to be done in our policy and what should not be done. In particular, energy solidarity should not be tinged with projects such as the expansion of Nord Stream. This investment, as in the lens, brings together all the reasons why we need the Energy Union so much.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: – Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking you for your role during the Paris climate conference. I would never have expected such a position during your hearing in the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, and thank you very sincerely for your role. I think that the Energy Union, if it wants to be that ambitious project, must ensure competitiveness, our energy security and minimise environmental and climate impacts. The whole project has a number of objectives, but I would like to highlight only two, those which I consider to be the core of the whole project and according to which the success of the Energy Union will be measured. The first is that the Energy Union will be a success if we can get rid of fossil fuel dependency in the next three, four or five decades. We need to create a framework where not only businesses, manufacturers, but also consumers, science and research can make appropriate decisions. But a much more immediate problem is to fulfil the essence of solidarity between Member States. And if we have a problem, it is the lack of solidarity, or perhaps the absence of it at all.  A concrete example is the expansion of the Nord Stream pipeline, the so-called Nord Stream 2 project. Without interest in, without consulting and circumventing the Member States and their partners, this is not solidarity between Member States, in my opinion. Nord Stream 2 does not diversify our supplies, it only harms the interests of Central and Eastern Europe. It is a disgrace to this European Commission if such a project happens.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by At the outset, I would like to thank Mark Gróbarczyk, the author of this report, very warmly, because this is a very good and very balanced document. Mr Gróbarczyk draws attention to security of supply and energy solidarity – two key dates when it comes to the Energy Union, and this is very important. However, the construction of Nord Stream 2, the increase in Nord Stream capacity, violates these fundamental principles of the Energy Union and we should not absolutely agree to that. Finally, I expect the Commissioner to say very clearly and decisively 'no' to this project.  I turn to colleagues who criticise the right of states to shape their own energy mixes. Do you doubt the fundamental treaties of the European Union, since, on the basis of those Treaties, each Member State has the right to decide on its energy mix? I would point out that decarbonisation is a bad road, it is a way nowhere for countries that, like Poland, have coal-based energy in eighty percent. Do you not think it is worth supporting modern technologies such as coal gasification? Isn't it worth spending the Juncker Plan on clean coal technologies?

name: Pilar del CASTILLO VERA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, for energy integration in the Union, it is clear — and it is almost tautological to say — that connections are needed; for there to be connections it is necessary to operate where there are major emergencies. That is why, in October 2014, the Council stated in its statement that it instructed the Commission, supported by the Member States, to take urgent action to achieve a minimum target of 10% of interconnections of existing electricity as a matter of urgency and by 2020.  It is clear that integration has to take place at the regional level, that integration has to be produced through this type of interconnections for those countries, as the rapporteur himself and other Members have said, that they are more disconnected, further away, that they are more islands. That is why it is striking that this political decision of 10% is classified as a lack of scientific basis. This doesn't really make any sense. It is a political objective based on a certain fact and, therefore, we must always act proportionately, as has always happened in the European Union for the purposes of integration. Those who have the most needs, the more urgency they have in solving it. You have to integrate and not create, well, a little bit of this unease that is sometimes created about who has priorities and who doesn't. I believe that the priorities are everyone's; but of some, immediately, more than others, because they are in a lower capacity situation.  (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Peter ERIKSSON
text: blue-card question. – I agree with almost everything you say, but it is also important to have evidence-based checks on what you are doing, because we are dealing with taxpayers’ money. We should only use taxpayers’ money in as effective a way as possible. It is perhaps not the most efficient thing to lay a new cable from Cyprus to Greece to solve this problem. Maybe it is better to invest in electricity and renewables in Cyprus itself, for example.

name: Pilar del CASTILLO VERA
text: "blue card" response. – I believe that we must distinguish, dear rapporteur, between what is a political objective and what then are the measures to develop that objective.  The political objective is based on a certain fact. That fact is true that there is greater disintegration – a number of countries, not a few – are outside, and that is why we must deal with it.  The truth is that classifying that as lack of scientific evidence is somewhat strange. The list of policy objectives to be described as a lack of scientific evidence, it appears to be understood in this case, would be immense. So let's get over it.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: Mr President! Commissioner! Finally, an international climate agreement was reached. Finally, we have succeeded in committing the world to a showdown with fossil fuels. After all, one of our most visionary projects in this showdown is our own project here in the EU: the Energy Union is a fantastic vision, a strong framework for our climate and energy goals. But without effective regulation to be put into that framework, we will never achieve the goals!  We know from our own energy regulator, ACER, that in 70% of cross-border electricity connections in Europe, less than half – less than half – of available capacity is used. We therefore have cables, literally, both at sea, on land and in the air, and we have an increasing share of renewable energy, yet green energy is all too rarely reaching across borders between EU countries. Instead, local coal and gas power stations are just a little more fired up, and that is not a very green sustainable future.  ACER has given us a clear picture of the situation with its annual market report, and the conclusion is clear: energy is there, the capacity is there, cooperation between countries is fundamentally lacking. Artificial and real energy bottlenecks are a daily obstacle to the green transition and a gift to the old, polluting power stations. It is time for the Commission to address this problem, give ACER the cross-border skills they need and ensure that we do not just have an energy union in the EU, but a climate and energy union.   (The speaker agrees to answer a blue card question in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Dear sir, you spoke of energy solidarity, and in this solidarity you spoke of decarbonisation. On the other hand, you did not say that the Nord Stream project, the increase in its capacity, violates this fundamental principle of solidarity. On what basis do you ask that the Treaty provisions on the right of a Member State to shape its own energy mix should be departed from? After all, the Paris climate summit does not violate this.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: blue-card answer. – I am not sure whether the speaker actually understood my speech, but what I was emphasising was that we need more connections and more regulation about connections in Europe, because we need to have a free flow of energy between our European countries. I can also tell the speaker that I also find Nord Stream 2 a very problematic project; it is something we have to fight for many reasons – geopolitical reasons, environmental reasons, and also reasons relating to the transition of our energy system in the EU. I agree with you on that, but I think you misunderstood part of my speech.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: – Mr President, the single market means primarily networks: gas and electricity, mainly. There is a need for investment in the interconnection of national networks and, for this, there is a need not only for funding, but also for political will. Joint projects are a win. The Commission must decide at national network level on the list of joint projects taking into account the level of interconnection with neighbouring States, the delivery capacity available, the existing absorption capacity, the development of national networks.  I believe that more important than the 10% or any other percentage in the future is the assessment of the need for interconnection on the basis of the production-consumption situation in each Member State. The energy mix is a national task. We must respect the environment, but also the needs of the economy. Coal must remain as a raw material for energy production, with the application of modernisation and emission stakes measures.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: – Mr President, we need to promote an Energy Union with clean, secure and affordable energy. We need to promote an Energy Union in which citizens and local authorities play a central part and we realise the potential of the North Sea. We need an Energy Union in which the most vulnerable citizens are not left aside. Energy efficiency is the first fuel. It is about security. It is about savings. It is about energy poverty and health.  Resistance to high, ambitious and binding targets on energy efficiency is inconsistent and irresponsible. I am hopeful that Parliament will give a progressive vision of the Energy Union tomorrow. We owe this to ourselves and to our future generations.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE). Mr President, I believe that everyone must now be made aware that the European Energy Union is the utmost imperative for the European Union itself. We must all work in this direction. It is inconceivable that the European Union should be so energy dependent that it needs over EUR 1 billion each year to meet its energy needs from energy imports. The numbers are false and relentless. It is not possible for it to be 90% dependent on crude oil, to be 66% dependent on natural gas and for some to oppose the policy of strengthening the Energy Union. But energy detoxification and the Energy Union will not materialise if the European Union itself does not fulfil its potential, wherever they are.  I will refer to our example of Cyprus. Natural gas reserves have been found in the Eastern Mediterranean and there is now a strong alliance between Cyprus, Greece, Israel and Egypt, of an energy nature, which the Energy Union can exploit. Addressing the Commissioner, I would like to stress that this is a good opportunity for Europe to focus on the region and to move on to energy infrastructure and investment and the exploitation of the Eastern Mediterranean.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your support. Perhaps the historic success of the Paris climate summit will put an end to the almost exclusive world domination of hydrocarbons, which has characterised us over the past century. Just as oil and gas replaced coal in the 20th century, fossil fuels will now be replaced as the only ones, at least in our hopes, by renewable energies. This is not some green policy, it is not a mere environmental issue, it is an economic rationality that no European government can withdraw from.  As the European Union works together on a common energy policy, there are some governments in the Member States that would rather torpedo this. There are those who want to build a new gas pipeline with separate passenger policies, and there are those who want to build a new nuclear power plant with a Russian billionaire gigacredit. It's all the wrong way! This does not mean national sovereignty, but circumvention of the whims of international energy policy by the States they represent. That is why the common European energy community should be chosen instead of the specific passenger policy of the Member States.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: PPE). Mr President, energy security, adequacy and the lowest possible price are for consumers, throughout Europe, the demands of what we are discussing today, the Energy Union. What can we do about it? Firstly, we must encourage the construction of networks in South-Eastern Europe, where my country, Greece, is located, and support, through the Connecting Europe Facility but also the European Fund for Strategic Investments of the Juncker package, efforts to move the links forward immediately, not only with Italy, but also with countries such as Turkey and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. It is important for the European Union to lead this initiative, because this will increase energy security.  Secondly, the internal market and competition must operate in each Member State, since the energy mix falls within national policy and since clean technologies are necessary. In my country, Greece, there is an issue with private access to all energy sources. Private producers do not have equal access to lignite, so at the moment they are favoured because of low oil prices vis-à-vis PPC, but in the end competition does not work and consumers pay for it. We must also encourage consumers with regard to bilateral contracts with suppliers. It is consumers who we ultimately need to protect; (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 172(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – I drew attention to the part of your speech that concerned gas purchases. When the Energy Union project came out, it was reported by Donald Tusk, who talked about joint gas purchases for the whole of the European Union. What do you think of this project and would this plan not fit best in your assessment of the principle of solidarity? Because today we have a situation where Poland is one of the countries that pays the most expensive russian gas in the European Union, much more expensive than the French or Germans.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: PPE), answer with "blue card". – I did not mention gas, but I can gladly reply that I am clearly in favour of all the Member States having and, ultimately, the Union itself, many different suppliers. In this way we will also be able to have a gas pool and we will be able to eventually lower prices, which will benefit consumers in all Member States.

name: Adam GIEREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The Energy Union project is the proverbial one equation with three unknowns. At the same time, energy security, competitiveness and the achievement of climate objectives cannot be ensured without modifying the climate and energy package that discriminates against certain countries. A law is needed to enable Member States to pursue these three policy objectives independently, but jointly and severally, in a way that takes into account their GDP per capita. It is micro-efficiency indicators at company level and others for macro-efficiency across Member States, including transmission efficiency rather than energy constraints, that should be a tool for achieving climate targets. The Efficiency Directive needs to be improved and the ETS should take into account the internal coherence between emission allowances, efficiency and the share of RES so that they are promoted by an increase in those allowances. Administratively imposed benchmarks do not provide such opportunities.

name: Lara COMI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I think it is absolutely appropriate to create a sustainable energy environment, not only to guarantee energy security, naturally seeking to reduce prices, but above all to achieve the climate objectives, such as respecting the average global temperature increase within two degrees agreed at the Paris Summit.  Energy security also means diversifying supply, thus reducing dependence on fossil fuels, such as oil, gas, coal and focusing on renewable energy. We must strive to make the energy union a real engine of growth and investment, especially for green energy, employment and competitiveness, by investing, as I said earlier, also in renewable technologies, clean transport, smart homes and new ways of producing; to encourage the production and penetration of the market and the use of alternative biological and other fuels. So to actually achieve a green economy, a effectively sustainable economy, with positive repercussions not only on energy saving, therefore from an economic point of view, but also on reducing the greenhouse effect.  It will therefore also be necessary – and I will end here – to carry out a review of the energy label because we must give consumers a clear, precise idea of what information and savings for citizens will actually be.

name: Martina WERNER
text: Thank you, Mr President, also for the very good German. After long intensive discussions in committee, we have managed to produce a really very balanced report on the Energy Union. That is why I would also like to express my special thanks to the rapporteur and to the shadow rapporteurs. This report was produced in the run-up to the climate conference. On Saturday, something historic happened at COP 21: the first global climate treaty is in place. The trend is also quite clear: away from environmentally harmful and CO2-heavy fossil energy sources, towards renewables and energy efficiency. The report on the Energy Union reflects this trend, and that is why we are calling, particularly to the Council, for binding energy and climate targets for 2030. Prioritisation of renewables and energy efficiency and a new electricity market design for sustainable and decentralised energy supply.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: – Imagine a grocery store! And there is only one manufacturer of goods in this grocery store. What is it? I would call it the Soviet Union. It was. There was no competition in the shops. There was only one manufacturer's merchandise, if any. I thought about the energy situation for a moment. We are actually in a similar situation where we lack competition in the European Union. So we have prices too expensive, we have no choice, we have a very high import dependency. To free up the market, the shops only had to open doors, let competitors come in, everything stood in place. That was what happened when the Soviet Union collapsed. In order to open up the energy market, we now have this energy union, which will actually do the same. First of all, we need physical interconnections, both in electricity and in the gas market between Member States. We will have to break down all the barriers that come from regulators that restrict the market when even physically he would be able to. We got rid of the Soviet Union, we will also get rid of this situation where we do not have a free market in the field of energy.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – With regard to the Energy Union and the transmission of electricity, which is the content of these two reports, I would like to offer my sincere congratulations to the rapporteurs, as well as to the Commissioner and to all those who have made great progress on environmental objectives in Paris.  Allow me to support, in the context of these two reports, in particular the area that talks about providing additional funding for the Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators ACER. I myself have visited this agency, located in Ljubljana, and I know what options we would have and the benefits for European consumers if we were to provide them with the right conditions for work, because with good regulation we can reduce energy prices.  I support that part of the report that talks about more use of renewable sourcing in South-East Europe, in the Balkans, but also about countries getting their energy mixes, so that they can also avoid energy poverty, which means that people cannot pay for electricity because of low incomes, high energy prices or low quality buildings. It is all the job of the states to do their own work.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union is being strengthened by the conclusion of the historic Agreement of the Paris Conference on Climate Change.  In addition to laying the foundations for the salvation of the planet, it is a strength of the European Union as a whole and is a sure road to a robust and stable European Energy Union, which is therefore the real institutional and political challenge. It is well known that the current existence of economic, regulatory and administrative barriers to energy consumption does not protect and rather exacerbate energy poverty.  I therefore agree with the report and stress the key role of emissions trading issues, the necessary introduction of a real-driving emissions test, the decarbonisation of the air, sea and land transport sector still excluded from binding commitments, the reintroduction of waste into the economy as a raw material for a genuine circular economy and the achievement of the 10% target of electricity interconnection and the improvement of the functioning of the internal electricity market in the Union. European. These are all key issues for achieving a secure, independent, inclusive, transparent and competitive Energy Union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the European Union's energy strategy continues to promote, not only out of obsession but, above all, out of self-interest, the accounting and ownership separation of public electricity generation and transmission undertakings, with a view to the complete liberalisation of European electricity markets, but which will increase energy poverty in Greece and the other countries of the European South. At the same time, Brussels is turning a blind eye to the enormous problems created in some countries of the Union by these privatisations.  We denounce this policy that the Troika is trying to implement in Greece with the loss-making sale to PPC of 49% of ADMEE which ultimately aims, in due course, at the complete sell-off of PPC itself, after it has led to obsolescence. In practice, there can be no strong energy strategy for Greece without strong PPC. Moreover, the Energy Union strategy actually serves nothing other than the interests of European multinationals active in the energy sector, while at the same time limiting the sovereign rights of the Member States of the Union to formulate and design an independent energy policy.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, a serious European Union requires a common energy market that ensures the safety and resilience of the system, eliminates our dependence on third parties, promotes the decarbonisation, innovation and integration of consumers and producers and eliminates competition problems not only external but also internal. We have talked a lot about energy prices in the United States and China and their comparison with Europeans, but we talk less about the distortions we have in the internal market.  The effort that a Basque industrialist, for example, makes in innovation, efficiency, procedures, internationalisation, is offset by its competitors in other areas of the Union with an insulting differential in the price they pay for energy. Let us add to this the different credit conditions and agree that this is not the case with free competition in the internal market. That is why, for us, the target of immediate electrical interconnection of at least 10% is inplaceable, such as the legislative initiatives announced by the Commissioner and 15% of the interconnection by 2030.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: "Mr. President, Dear Commissioner, we have forgotten about the citizens again in today's debate. I would like to reiterate how important the role of local government, small businesses and citizens is in creating energy efficiency through investment in advanced networks, through the transformation of cities according to the concept of smart city. It is of utmost importance that the European Union and the Member States recognise the importance of engaging citizens in the energy transition through collective initiatives such as cooperatives and to remove economic, regulatory and administrative barriers. However, this is not enough.  We need to invest in citizen education and gradually change the culture of consumer behaviour through lifelong education. In the real circular economy we connect with the Energy Union, we need to return waste to the economy as a raw material, so preparing for reuse and recycling is much more of a priority than burning.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). Mr President, the European Energy Union is a utopia. Those who embrace it, whether they dream, or promote financial interests that do not treat the citizens of the countries as energy consumers. Energy poverty will continue to exist. The Union is heavily dependent on imports of crude oil, natural gas and coal. And what does he do in relation to that? On the one hand, it commits suicide by imposing sanctions on Russia, a key supplier, and on the other hand it does not contribute either to the proclamation or to the protection of the EEZ of Greece and Cyprus against the aggression of the Turks. This is an inviolable rule: European energy security must ensure the European security and sovereignty of European countries without exception or asterisks. When we use natural resources as a means of foreign policy and destabilisation, and I am thinking mainly of Germany, we are not only undermining economic growth but also democratic stability in Europe and the independence of sovereign states. Only national capacity mechanisms for the production and exploitation of national resources can contribute to energy independence and the sustainable development of an ever-shrinking Europe, ethnologically, anthropologically, Christianly and socially.

name: Brian HAYES
text: – Mr President, I fully support the priority objective of an Energy Union and we need to move quickly in this direction. We are not going to get the growth we all want to see across the 28 Member States of the European Union unless we have a sufficient energy supply. It is crucially important that we back the Framework Convention (FC) proposals, the Juncker Plan, and use the opportunity of investment so that we can get more interconnectors and get more networks in place to make sure that we have the infrastructure in place to create a genuine Energy Union across the European Union.  I applaud the success of Paris last week. I come from Ireland, a country which imports over EUR 7 billion worth of energy every single year because we are at the end of a very long gas pipeline. We depend on others for our energy supply.  We need to invest in renewables. We need to invest in alternatives. We have got to make sure that energy becomes more efficient in our building, and all other things we need to do to make sure this Energy Union happens.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, this report contains the wickers to transform our energy model; sets the way for securing citizens, as well as businesses, access to energy at affordable prices; promotes self-consumption from renewable energy sources and proposes clear measures to combat energy poverty; it also recognizes the potential of the energy sector as a competitive factor and as an engine of innovation and job creation.  However, we know that the transition to this more sustainable, more democratic, more competitive and safer model is not neutral. That is why we must resist attempts to put the principle of technological neutrality on the table and we must continue to strongly promote renewable energy, in order to ensure European leadership.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr. President, I support the creation of a solid Energy Union that will ensure a stable supply of safe energy to Member States and their citizens on more favourable terms. The fact that the main points of supply at the moment are mainly politically unstable environments where energy serves not only as a means of trade, but also for political blackmail, should be an additional motive for us to create a common market for energy. Joint investments in infrastructure will guarantee stability in supply and regional access to infrastructure connectivity will give this plan full meaning. That is why, I would like to once again emphasize the need for the construction of lng terminals on Krk in Croatia, which in the future, I believe, will be a key energy hub for Central and Southeastern Europe.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the In fact, what is happening in Paris is historic, as has already been said. This makes the Energy Union and an energy transition even more necessary than ever before. It can also be said that the ambitious energy transition in Germany was clearly the right one. There is only one thing that was actually forgotten in Paris and which, in my view, too little attention is taken into account in the Energy Union: the potential energy that can come from the sea, from the ocean. Indeed, it is predicted that, even though wave energy and tidal energy are still in their infancy, this may sooner or later account for 10% of Europe's energy supply. One must also consider that tidal energy, for example, is very predictable, so it is easy to plan that wave energy is particularly strong in winter, especially when the sun shines less and we have less solar energy.  I think it is very important to take this into account, and I would ask you, Commissioner and everyone else, to take the ocean even more into account in future, especially in the long-term energy planning.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: – Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, when we launched the framework strategy for an energy union, we set out to target measures specifically aimed at lowering energy costs for household consumers. A year later, I note with concern that more work is needed before we reach an energy market that supports European households and that the reduction in the energy price is significantly reflected in the bills paid.  The energy mix specific to each state must include both indigenous and locally or individually developed sources, in particular renewable ones. An investment climate favourable to them can contribute to the modernisation of energy infrastructure. In addition, access to cheap energy efficiency technologies can encourage entrepreneurship, especially among young people.  Energy security is an essential element of the Energy Union. In this respect, electricity market coupling projects in the Central and Eastern European region should be opened to the South-East region and alternative energy supply routes should be continuously exploited.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, achieving agreement in respect of an Energy Union that acknowledges the importance of tackling the unsustainable use of fossil fuels and increased use of clean, green renewables instead is ever more important. I have just spent three days back in my North-West England constituency witnessing first-hand the devastating and costly effects of Storm Desmond, an unprecedented extra—tropical cyclone which has made thousands homeless, rendered property uninsurable and already resulted in job losses, with 1 000 people immediately laid off at the famous McVitie’s biscuit factory in Carlisle just before Christmas. The real cost of failure in agreeing a progressive, sustainable Energy Union will be more of the same. We must act now, for the benefit of everybody’s future.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank all the ladies and gentlemen of your very interesting interventions. Let me, however, make a little clarification: some Member has suggested that, in developing the Energy Union, the Commission was invading the competences of the Member States. Nothing further, Mr President, from reality. It was the European Council which asked the Commission to put in place all the rules to ensure that the European Union is a security of energy supply, energy production in a sustainable manner and to have energy at competitive prices.  Let us not deceive ourselves, we have security of supply problems in two ways: on the one hand, we have a very strong dependence on single suppliers in the gas sector – and that is why the European Commission has supported the Southern Corridor – and on the other hand there is all the realization of interconnections in the eastern Mediterranean, in the Baltic countries... we also try to connect the Iberian Peninsula to the gas markets... And that is why the European Council set policy objectives, which have been said in this House, of 10% and 15% in electricity markets. It is impossible to develop an internal market without physical interconnections. Then, much more needs to be done: energy charging systems, renewable energy support systems must be harmonized; enormous harmonization and integration must be made. But there is one very clear fact: when there is regional integration, competition increases and consumers benefit. When there are no connections, we rely on external suppliers and set prices from outside. That is why, on the gas market, in addition to interconnections, the Commission wants to launch a liquefied natural gas strategy, so that there are other alternative sources.  And that's why in the electricity market we work on a double front: improving interconnections, but also redesigning the electricity market so that we have smart networks, effective interconnection systems, more harmonized charging systems, and we can move from having 28 distinct electricity markets to aiming, in the first phase, for more powerful regional integration and, in the end, definitive integration.  But, in addition to this process of developing the energy union, we are in the midst of a great global climate agreement, for which the European Union presented the most ambitious objectives, both in reducing greenhouse gases, as well as energy efficiency and renewables.  But those are the goals we have today. In Paris we have designed a system to progressively raise our level of ambition; today we are on a path not towards both degrees but towards three degrees. That is why, in 2018, we will assess together where we are and in 2020 all parties to the Convention will be asked to say whether they increase their level of ambition or confirm what they have. And, in 2023, we will repeat this exercise.  But there's a fact that's very clear. All countries in the world are moving in the same direction: greater development of renewables, greater energy efficiency and better management of their forest masses. And that's an unstoppable process. What the Commission wants is to prepare the European Union for this process, with the best legislation, with the greatest ambition.  We have to make our prices no longer twice as high as those of our competitors in electricity, or three times as much in gas. And that is why the Commission is not going to spare any means. For this and for us to be a reliable part of this great Paris agreement that fulfils its commitment to reduction, that improves its energy competitiveness and that has a market where consumers benefit. And, of course, to address the issue of energy poverty.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: deputy rapporteur. – Mr President, we have heard a number of views today on the various aspects of the Energy Union. But perhaps we can all agree on one thing: the European Union needs energy, and the Energy Union can help us take our competitiveness and security to the next level. Everyone, consumers and industry, should benefit from a well-functioning energy market. I think that the whole report was very well characterised by my colleague Petersen, who said that this is a report that has balanced ambitions and a realistic view together on such a complex matter as energy within Europe. I would therefore like to thank the shadow rapporteurs once again on behalf of my friend Mark Gróbarczyk and reiterate my belief that we will hopefully be able to approve tomorrow, vote in a balanced report that combines all these energy interests and does not divide and escalate in such a complex area as energy.

name: Peter ERIKSSON
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I would also like to thank my shadow rapporteurs and those who have worked with the Energy Union and also thank you for the discussion with Commissioner Cañete, because it has been a very interesting and important debate that we have had here today, and everyone should know that we have great tasks ahead of us.  These are very serious major climate change that is coming and will change our planet. We still have a great dependence on fossil energy. We import the majority of energy into the European Union. We have very high prices and weak competitiveness in several countries because of excessive energy prices. Many also have regulated prices and therefore not a functioning market, but there are two things that make me more optimistic about the future than before. It is partly that the prices of renewable energy have fallen dramatically in recent years, and that means that we have much greater opportunities to make large investments meaningful in renewable energy and to bring more renewable energy into the energy mix.  The second thing is what has happened this weekend, when we got a climate agreement that actually means that all the countries of the earth are behind work to achieve less than the 2°C target. We have great opportunities, including by investing in a common electricity market in Europe, of bringing back more competitiveness, of bringing in more renewable energy and also of getting cheaper energy for consumers.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I would also like to thank Mr Gróbarczyk, who was not here, who prepared this report. At the moment he is a minister in the Polish government, but we remember his work.  I close the debate.  The vote will take place on Tuesday 15 December 2015.  Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – The Energy Union is a recognition of the fact that we require a collective and coherent response which ensures energy security and climate and economic resilience by investing more in low-carbon infrastructure and new technologies. Europe’s energy and climate strategies must be complementary to one another and not contradictory. We need to attack emissions not energy production. We need to be realistic. Whilst having a strategy to phase out polluting technologies we need to keep in mind that many of our Member States require a transitory period to reach our ultimate aim of having energy produced from renewables. In this regard LNG can be the perfect complement to renewables. This fits in with our goal of having a resilient Energy Union with an ambitious climate policy that gives consumers – households and businesses – secure, sustainable, competitive and affordable energy.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. – The internal energy market in the European Union needs common standards for smart grids, which are key elements for ensuring stable supply and free flow of energy across borders, as well as investments for smaller-scale gas and electricity interconnections linking neighbouring regions. In order to develop these interconnection lines, it is beneficial for all European citizens to have better cooperation between the Commission and the Member States and, in particular, between the Commission and regional authorities. In addition, this cooperation can contribute to adequate planning of energy supply and demand at the level of the EU internal energy market and ensure cost-optimal security of supply. On the other hand, those interconnection lines will allow electricity networks to redirect energy from surplus areas to deficient areas, thus enabling the market to respond instantly to supply shortages wherever they occur and to compensate for circadian and seasonal cycles.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: in writing. – It is imperative to reach, in the short term, and as a minimum objective in terms of interconnections, the 10% of installed generation capacity, as well as the 15% by 2030. This priority brought together the consensus of the European Commission, the Council and this Parliament in the previous parliamentary term. I am therefore sorry that, in a way, the Eriksson report, which is under discussion today, seems to call this priority into question. We have persistently seen the maintenance of what is a market failure, in the resolution of which we have an obligation to engage politically, without yielding to vested interests, which for years or even decades have prevented adequate integration of the energy market. Not to do so would be to condemn several Member States to their peripheral condition, not only of energy but also to economic. I therefore voted in favour of the amendments which point to ways to strengthen that objective.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Energy security and the related diversification of energy supply and sources underpinning the Energy Union are undoubtedly among the key issues that we should be striving for with determination. Unfortunately, the European Union is dependent on external energy supplies and unfortunately this situation is deteriorating, posing a threat to the use of energy supplies for political purposes.  Unfortunately, I regret the fact that projects such as the construction of the Nord Stream gas pipeline are completely contrary to the objectives of the Energy Union and show a disconnect between rhetoric and real action. I am therefore of the opinion that in these difficult times, when, as I think we never need solidarity and joint action before, we should make every effort to ensure that the energy security objectives contained in the draft Energy Union are not an empty record on paper, but a real signpost for the actions of all Member States. At the same time, I believe that, while climate policy and action are undoubtedly needed and important, it should be borne in mind that setting overly ambitious, binding energy and climate targets can have negative effects and be particularly difficult to achieve for some Member States.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. – This report, rightly, acknowledges that it is for Member States to determine their energy mix and that it is a sovereign decision of each Member State on how to decarbonise its economy. There is, however, a role for EU level coordination of policies and technological development, in order to deliver on Europe’s and Member States’ climate and energy targets. Ensuring a much higher level of interconnectivity between national power systems is essential for ensuring a more flexible, decentralised and sustainable energy sector, and facilitating an increase of renewable energy. My country, Scotland, is well placed to harness its abundance of resources in the form of wave, wind and tidal generating potential. A sensibly prioritised EU Energy Union will give due priority to supporting the provision of interconnectors, so that Scotland’s potential surplus electricity can be sold to the mainland European market, where guaranteeing long-term security of supply is necessary.  While I support the idea of an Energy Union in principle, there are some aspects of the report that we will vote on tomorrow that I cannot support. For instance there is, in my view, unacceptably strongly worded support for nuclear generation, and EU financing thereof. I cannot support that.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: in writing. – In the past year, I have seen the nuclear industry come back with false arguments about the major role of nuclear to reduce CO2 emissions while taking every opportunity to secure public funding. First of all, 1.8% of energy consumed in the world in 2013 was of nuclear source according to the International Energy Agency's Statistics.  Therefore, it can hardly be argued that nuclear energy makes difference to protect our climate while the safety and environmental risks certainly outweigh its meagre contribution to CO2 reduction, despite all contrary propaganda from the companies.  Nuclear is expensive and not profitable - the proof of this is in the report: "nuclear energy should be supported in any form by the EU financial mechanisms or by the EU financial institutions;" AND "EU provides an enabling framework for those Member States that wish to pursue new nuclear power projects to do so, within EU internal market and competition rules;" These are desperate lobby efforts, and we cannot let European taxpayer's money be invested in outdated technologies that will create infrastructure-lock-in and take away precious public funds. We need to stop this from happening! Please vote for renewables and energy efficiency, a cheaper and safer ways to our CO2 emissions!

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. – In light of the long-term target of achieving 80-95% reduction of greenhouse gases by 2050, the purpose of the future Energy Union is to ensure a free flow of energy across Member States. I support the initiative of a future Energy Union plan that enables EU consumers to access gas, electricity and heating in a sustainable, democratic and cost-effective manner. According to the report, the EU’s fragmented energy market has a severe impact on Europe’s competitiveness and energy security.  The report stresses the increased demand for an efficient internal energy market that can deliver energy taking into account factors such as safety, social and environmental responsibility and affordable distribution. Alongside market integration, price convergence is also a pressing concern taking into account the variable costs provided by different energy sources. The report underlines that it is imperative to support local production of energy (primarily renewable) and to pursue up-to-date technological changes, alongside new modes of production and consumption trends such as electric vehicles. As mentioned in the report, I emphasise the upmost importance of a cohesive internal energy market, alongside interconnectedness and resilience between the national and the Union’s energy security and market objectives.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. – It is symbolic that today, when my colleagues in the European Parliament in Strasbourg are debating a resolution on European electricity connections, the long-awaited electricity connections with Sweden (NordBalt) and Poland (LitPol Link) are officially lit in Lithuania. Thanks to the stubbornness of the Baltic states and the support of the European Union, one of the most isolated energy islands has disappeared today. Thanks to the built electricity bridges, the Baltic states have become full players in the European market.  This is a joyous message for cheaper electricity customers. This is also good news for local energy producers, because the connections will allow electricity to be exported.  This is also good news for all who care about our environment, because connections are a prerequisite for the development of renewable sources. In a word, this is a good day for all of us who want an independent, secure energy system beyond third-country suppliers. It is true that the Baltic states remain, in a way, russian dependence, because the electricity transmission system itself is still managed from Moscow. I would therefore like to congratulate my colleague, Peter Eriksson, who, in his report on electrical connections, also points to the so-called problem of synchronisation of electrical systems in the Baltic states. It is not normal that even the transmission systems of three EU Member States operate in another political and economic area. I hope that the European Parliament, by voting in favour of this resolution, will express its full support for the synchronisation of the Baltic transmission system with continental European networks.

name: Algirdas SAUDARGAS
text: Writing. – The agreement at the climate change conference is even more relevant for the creation of a European Energy Union. In the global context of energy and geopolitics, the European Energy Union needs to be effective and able to respond appropriately and adapt to new challenges. The report is a compromise text and cannot therefore be perfectly balanced. However, I believe that the objectives and measures of the Energy Union are clearly identified in it. Sufficient attention shall be paid to internal aspects of the Energy Union, such as the completion of the internal market, security of supply, infrastructure, energy efficiency or greenhouse gas reduction. However, there is no need to put a genuine European energy policy into the second plan. The recent vision for the European Energy Union, I think, is still lacking, and we are also seeing from the decision on the development of the Nordstream 2 pipeline. Solidarity is often expressed in words rather than by action. I am convinced that the success of the Energy Union will depend not on the objectives set above, but on how we can achieve them. I therefore believe that enhanced supervision and control by the Commission is necessary. I would like to call on colleagues to concentrate on those energy policies where consensus is possible. The Commission has already presented its first annual report on the Energy Union since last month, and I hope that Parliament will also be able to formulate its position in a timely manner.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: in writing. – We are discussing again in the European Parliament the single European energy market, which, however, does not exist. Because of this, European citizens pay more for energy. In the absence of a single market and therefore competition at European level, large national energy companies have the possibility of obtaining annuities borne by consumers in each Member State. It is inexplicable and to condemn the resistance of some Member States that do not actually want competition at European level, defending their own companies. That is why it is time to make visible progress in achieving the European Single Energy Market.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. – In Paris an irreversible step has been taken in the right direction for the sustainability of the planet. The energy transition is not the only instrument to achieve the goals, but it is the most important. The European Union must put the Energy Union and the Single Energy Market into practice firmly to lead and set an example in the fight against global warming and to begin a decisive path of economic change towards growth, the creation of quality jobs and the fight against inequalities. Investing in renewable energies, smart grids, new models of urban organization, sustainable mobility, energy efficiency of buildings and public spaces, new services and models of industrial production, calls, on the one hand, the capacity for innovation and creativity and, on the other hand, gives purpose and focus to fundamental research and applied research. The Union's energy sovereignty and the plurality of sources of supply must be shared, building a market capable of making clean and cheap energy reach households and businesses, ensuring the target of minimum interconnections of 10% by 2020 and their clear overcoming in the following years.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I have had the privilege of being your rapporteur on the Trademarks Package since the spring of 2012. I would like to take this opportunity to thank all colleagues and their staff, both in Parliament and the Commission. I would also like to warmly thank the many Presidencies that have worked on this dossier, and perhaps most importantly the Italian and the Latvian Presidencies, which provided excellent work in the most critical stages of the negotiations. I would like to draw your attention to the achievements on this file. The reforms agreed in trialogues will ensure that companies in Europe have faster and cheaper access to trademarks, both at national and European levels, without compromising on the quality of the decisions. Administrative procedures have been streamlined according to best practices, and we will see an increased harmonisation of the national systems along the lines of best practices. On substantive trademark law, we have modernised a number of provisions in view of technological developments. We have also managed to include important safeguards to protect freedom of expression by limiting the possibility of rightholders to bring legal actions against people using trademarks for reasons, for example, of parody or artistic expression. For this, I would like to thank an old colleague from Sweden who was with us but who is not any more. He drew our attention to this.  Some of you might have received letters during the week from NGOs expressing concerns on the issue of transit of generic medicines to developing countries. I would very much like to underline the position and the fact: I can assure everyone that there will in no case be any problems for the transit of generic medicines to developing countries as a result of this legislation. Throughout my life I have fought for development, and I would never, ever allow a law bearing my name to hinder people in developing countries from getting access to medicines. That is for sure. The ambition has been shared by the entire Parliament negotiating team. We have been united in this, and together we managed to include very strong safeguards. It should also be noted that the problems that have occurred in past times with regard to the transit of medicines have exclusively related to patents, and not trademarks. I am proud today of the balance that we have achieved between fighting organised crime and the dangerous trafficking of counterfeit products, and protecting the interests of legitimate trade. I would like to stress that there is no risk of confusion between generic medicines and counterfeit, fake medicines. Any holder of a European trademark trying to incorrectly stop goods in transit which are not breaching the rights is also liable for damages in accordance with the EU customs regulations. These rules will give our customs officers the right to seize counterfeit fake products transiting through Europe. Now, in Europe, we will be able to help developing countries in an important struggle against organised crime, which preys on the most vulnerable of us. This is something that we are all united in.  I will come back later, but I look forward to the debate on this item.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, firstly I would like to warmly thank the Committee on Legal Affairs and congratulate the rapporteur, Cecilia Wikström, for the excellent and successful work on the trade mark reform package. Both this work and the very constructive spirit that I observed in the negotiations facilitated reaching an agreement after more than two years of complex discussions.  Regardless of its apparently technical character, the trade mark reform package constitutes a key element for the EU’s competitiveness and innovation strategy. The reform package will foster innovation and growth by making the trade mark registration system all over the EU more accessible and efficient for businesses, whether in terms of lower cost, increased speed, more predictability or legal certainty. The clear benefits of the compromise package are there for all to see. The package marks a significant step in both the modernisation and the further harmonisation of the trade mark system in Europe. Allow me now to highlight just a few of these benefits. Firstly, the agreed fee reductions at European Union level will lead to savings of up to almost 40%, in particular for businesses that seek protection of the registered EU trademarks beyond an initial period of ten years.  Secondly, the reform of the directive will ensure more streamlined, efficient and harmonised registration procedures across all trademark offices in the European Union. Faster and less burdensome procedures will constitute a great improvement for growing companies, mainly SMEs, which roll out their business beyond one Member State and are seeking trade mark protection. The arrangements for common application requirements and the future availability of administrative opposition and cancellation procedures at national level are a good illustration of this.  Thirdly, trade mark owners in the EU will have better tools to fight against counterfeit goods, in particular when these illegal imitations are in transit through the EU’s territory. This will help prevent abuse of the Union and its transit routes in its role as a central hub for the worldwide distribution of such goods. At the same time there will be appropriate safeguards in the interest of legitimate trade.  And fourthly, the reform will bring modernised rules and increased legal certainty by adapting trade mark rules to the modern business environment and clarifying trade mark rights and their limitations. In relation to the regulation regarding the procedure of preselection and appointment of an executive director of the Agency in Alicante that is responsible for administering the EU trade mark system, it has to be stressed from the Commission’s point of view that the final text is not aligned with the principles of the EU’s interinstitutional common approach on decentralised agencies. Notwithstanding this shortcoming and also the fact that key elements of the Commission’s proposals concerning the budget were not retained, the final text of the regulation will nevertheless bring about major improvements in the governance and accountability of the Agency.  Thus, considering the overall compromise that has been achieved, the Commission welcomes very much and endorses the agreed compromise package.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, let me first of all thank all my colleagues in the Committee on Legal Affairs who participated in this reform, in particular the rapporteur, Cecilia Wikström.  The EU trade mark is already a very successful project, and I would still like to say that we have now managed to agree on amendments to the existing legislation that will have a positive impact on all those who use the trade marks. At the same time, I am convinced that the agreed reform will not have any major negative side effects in areas that may be affected by the trade mark regulation. I believe that the proposed arrangements will simplify and simplify the procedure, reduce fees and, overall, prove that EU legislation can be amended to the benefit of its users. The change in OHIM's name, as well as other changes resulting from the Treaty of Lisbon, are proof that the development of European law also allows for specific changes that are understandable to the general public. I am therefore convinced that we can support the proposed reform in good conscience.

text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. The European Union's trademark protection package is a key instrument in the fight against counterfeiting. How is this to be done? Our rapporteur, Mrs Wikström, mentioned what is particularly important to me about this package: we have been able to ensure that generic medicines continue to be available in developing countries. Health is so important that any trade-mark protection regime that we have here at European level should also absolutely ensure that generic medicines are actually delivered to developing countries. name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, a trade mark is a sign used to distinguish goods or services on the market. It helps us consumers to be easier to navigate in the range of products and services and to choose according to their revered wishes. Union protection systems will operate alongside national protection systems. The systems will not compete, but, as we have proposed, on the contrary, complement each other. We also have a better tool to combat pirated, counterfeit goods. The undeniable advantage of a European trade mark is that, by registering a single trade mark, its owners obtain uniform legal protection for their brand throughout the European Union. In addition to the increased legal certainty resulting from uniform legislation instead of twenty-eight different national arrangements, this entails a substantial reduction in the costs of registration, maintenance of national stamps and related legal services. And the whole process for the individual applicant is also cheaper. I appreciate that we have managed to find a solution to a number of contentious issues. I very much appreciate the fruitful cooperation with all the shadow rapporteurs and Cecilia, I want to thank you specifically for the medicines. Thank you for your attention and I wish the trademark "Merry Christmas".

text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Wikström, and the other shadow rapporteurs. This was the first file where I participated in tripartite negotiations and I have hopefully learned a lot from this very fascinating work. There is a great deal of good in this report. The system becomes simpler, smoother, it partly solves the problem that ohim managed to raise an enormous amount of money by handing out an enormous amount of brands, so there are very good things that are achieved. On the issue of freedom of expression and the issue of generic medicines, it was for us, the Greens, the most important issues in this report, and unfortunately, as far as generic medicines are concerned, I am not as sure as the other speakers that we made it all the way. We have just received a letter from the Médecins Border Accessibility Campaign and 49 other organisations about concerns that the right to generic medicines is not sufficiently guaranteed in this proposal. There is a concern, a risk, that generic medicines will be wrongly stopped in EU ports. We have tried to minimise that risk, but we greens want to say that we have not got far enough on this front. We fought for more, and I want to say that we did our best. The Greens will vote 'no', because this issue of generic medicines is the most important thing for us in this case.

text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Cecilia Wikström, for her work and all the other shadow rapporteurs.  Trademarks are extremely important for the European production system and this is even more true for some national subsystems, such as the Italian one where "Made in" is synonymous with indication of origin, quality, guarantee of marked products and services.  The reform of the Eu ropean Union's trade mark discipline is now reaching its goal, not without difficulty and not without critical issues. These include the failure to introduce an explicit 'fair use' clause which would have allowed a broader interpretation of the limitations of exclusive rights, whenever the latter must be balanced with freedom of artistic expression. However, we welcome the provision of a special recital guaranteeing respect for fundamental rights and freedoms and, in particular, freedom of expression. Equally welcome is the guarantee introduced for the free transit of generic medicines, without neglecting the need to combat trafficking in counterfeit medicines and cosmetics, which are therefore often extremely dangerous to the health of citizens.

name: Tadeusz ZWIEFKA
text: – Mr President, Honourable Commissioner, colleagues, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. It has taken almost three years for the Committee on Legal Remedies, as well as other Members of this House, to work on this great reform in order to actually introduce the necessary and necessary changes to the trade mark protection system in the European Union. The final success is undoubtedly a great credit to our rapporteur Cecilia Wikström, who has fought steadfastly for clearer and clearer rules, above all for trade mark owners. And this is a huge success. Much has been said here about the fight against counterfeiting, but this reform brings about other significant changes, such as cheaper and simpler trade mark registration, a clearer register of trade marks and clear rules on refusal of registration. These are extremely important issues. The most important thing, however, is that the common new rules that have just been prepared are effective, because if they are ineffective, it will only be a half-success. Therefore, the rules to prevent the appearance of counterfeits on the market, i.e. closer cooperation between national patent offices and, as well as between those offices and the EU agency, are key to the final success of introducing a modern and efficient EU trade mark system. name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: – Mr President, modernising the trade mark regime at European level will help the system to work better. This tool allows first and foremost the effective fight against counterfeit products and piracy. Counterfeiting costs go to 8% of international trade, and the ones who really lose are consumers. That is why our key objectives through this legislation have been related to public health, protecting jobs and defending fundamental rights.  I am pleased that the European Parliament has managed to reduce red tape by using this mechanism, increasing efficiency, but also reducing costs by up to 37%. The new regulations reduce the possibility of exceptions that may lead to abuse, but also allow for better coordination on products in transit. The generalisation of this system at European level will help beneficiaries. The fact that revenue balancing has been envisaged for the national trade mark bodies will increase the fairness of the European system.  In my country, I must say, Romania, consumers, therefore citizens, are unfortunately often misled by counterfeit products. That is why it is essential for the European Union to step up information and communication campaigns aimed at both citizens and companies – I am referring here in particular to SMEs – who are keen to secure trade mark protection. A strong common trade mark protection system will strengthen the European economy in relation to its competitors, and I want as many informed beneficiaries as possible from all European countries and, in particular, from my country, Romania.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: ECR). – First, congratulations on the victory, and now, honourable Madam Commissioner, honourable Members, I would like to thank My Colleague Vikström and the other shadow rapporteurs for their efforts. I think that after long and difficult negotiations, we were able to achieve a relatively good result. The agreement has many positive aspects and we in the ECR Group have also fought to achieve this good result.  One major concern of ours, however, remains the OHIM's budget surplus and the reference to the European Union budget. Yes, it is specified where and how it can be used, and the promises are to be used to combat copyright infringement.  However, in my view, and a large part of my group, this money should be returned to national intellectual property offices because they can best allocate exactly how it should be used and useful to those who have paid to have a Community trademark.  This money could be put, for example, into an anti-counterfeiting programme, but only national offices could determine where and for what those funds would best serve.

My sincere congratulations, honourable rapporteur, to you and your colleagues, who have prepared a demanding document in which you are facing a challenging area of counterfeiting, on the one hand, and, on the other, to building competitiveness, innovation and, at the same time, simplifying procedures, which is sometimes very difficult to achieve, because on the one hand you are chasing someone who is breaking the law and you are simplifying the procedures. name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the trademark protection system should be simple, inexpensive and flexible enough to give users access to protection that corresponds to their needs. For example, some users want protection only in one Member State, while others want uniform protection in all 28 Member States of the Union. For this reason, trademark protection at national level must be maintained at the same time. This means establishing a complementary relationship between the Union and national trademark protection systems. In this context, the principle of territoriality, legal certainty and clarity must be guaranteed, both in the case of similarity and in the case of the use of an identical trade mark for identical products. Particular attention should be paid to facilitating the branding and protection of small and medium-sized enterprises hit by the economic crisis and austerity, particularly in Greece and the countries of the European South.
