text: Mr. President, I want to warn you about one problem we're about to have. Namely, when we adopt the appropriate decisions regarding organic farming here, we will find ourselves in the situation that our trademark on which our stars, European stars, and is related to eco-products or bio-products, will be treated differently in different countries.  At issue is that what I insist on will not be take into into being, namely that this trade mark means indeed an eco-product or bio-product in all Member States in the same way. What's all this about? The amount of pesticides in one apple will be different in different Member States, and essentially we will have the same mark that will talk about it being the same eco-product or bio-product. I think this will be a big problem for consumers and there is a big consumer fraud coming up, and we know how sensitive the market for bio-based products and eco-products is.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I have listened carefully to your remarks and to your interventions. I would like to thank all of you for your contribution to this debate. In closing, let me stress a few key points.  Firstly, it has to be noted that trade-mark-intensive industries contribute enormously to economic performance and employment in the EU. The agreed reform would lead to a modernised, more efficient legal framework. This will promote entrepreneurship and competitiveness; which is certainly good for Europe.  We will also be better equipped to fight against counterfeiting. This is essential to help reduce its detrimental effect on health, on safety and of course on innovation and growth. Let me at this point also stress, and it is important to note, that the agreed compromise concerns trade marks only. It does not have any connection with patents or legal generic medicines. Nevertheless, the agreed package provides for appropriate safeguards to guarantee the smooth transit of generic medicines across the Union. Some of you referred to this.  I therefore commend this package to the European Parliament and I ask you for your strong support for this. This will send a very clear signal in terms of the EU’s ability to reform in economically significant areas whilst boosting innovation and growth.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, let me finally mention a few issues related to the governance and finance issues. Parliament has managed a number of important victories here as well; transparency has been increased in all areas of the agency, and Parliament will have a full seat on the board of the agency. The agency, previously known as the Office for the Harmonisation of the Internal Market, or OHIM, will change its name to the European Intellectual Property Office (EU IPO).  We have succeeded in lowering the fees as much as possible without interfering with the national systems, and will increase the funding dedicated to cooperation projects between the EU agency and national agencies, which will lead to soft harmonisation as well as capacity-building in the national offices.  All in all, this is a very large and complex dossier that will now come to an end and, as I have said many times throughout these years: this is not a revolution, it is a modernisation which was needed on the existing EU trade mark system.  I am convinced that this dossier will lead to the aim that we all share; namely to foster growth and prosperity for Europe, so badly needed these days. I trust that colleagues will support the agreement that we have reached and I thank you all again for your support and for very fruitful, and sometimes quite lively, work and discussions on this dossier. I wish you all the best.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The Commission, the Council and the European Parliament reached a final agreement at second reading on the trade mark reform package, which was officially approved by the Plenary Assembly on 14 December 2015. Not only has the rules changed, but the name of the Office for Harmonisation of the Internal Market (OHIM), which will now function as the European Union Office for the Protection of Intellectual Property (EUIPO), has changed.  The trademark-based industry accounts for 21% of all jobs and 34% of the Union's total GDP, according to a study last year by OHIM and the European Patent Office. Consequently, trade marks are currently one of the most important market instruments determining the position of the product designated on the market. A trade mark confers on its holder an exclusive right under which it may prohibit third parties from using it in the course of trade.  The reform of the trade mark system aimed at modernising the current system to keep pace with an ever-growing market for the benefit of all users, stimulating innovation and economic growth by increasing accessibility for businesses.  In conclusion, trade marks in the 21st century should register quickly and without unnecessary administrative burdens, while ensuring high quality services and a level of legal certainty. These amendments complement efforts to ensure the coexistence and complementarity of the EU system and national trade mark registration systems.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The ECR Group generally supports the European Commission's trade mark reform initiative, which does not propose a new system but targets modernising existing rules.  The aim of these measures is m.in. to align the terminology of legal acts with the Treaty of Lisbon, to organise cooperation between the Office for Harmonisation of the Internal Market and national offices, and to rationalise the procedures for the registration and registration of Community trade marks. Moreover, it may be a complication for some Member States to have the procedure for raising a plea alleiling that the earlier mark should not be brought before a court, which will result in a duplication of jurisdiction with the national Patent Office. name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. We will vote for more effective branding legislation. We want to make business life easier by making trademark registration simpler, faster, more reliable but also cheaper. The new rules provide: a) a strengthening of the means to combat counterfeit goods, especially those that pass through Europe - our continent can no longer be the platform for distributing imitations around the world for fraudsters of all kinds. Increased cooperation between national and European legislation will be a plus; (b) a significant reduction in the taxes payable when registering trademarks - the reduction in these costs could be as much as one third of the current cost; c) speeding up and simplifying procedures, which will make life easier for businesses, especially SMEs.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the Commission statement on the protection of victims of terrorism (2015/3019(RSP)).

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the recent attacks in Paris revealed once again the radical face of terrorism. We know that over the past decade several Member States have been targeted and experienced tragic losses. Let me mention all of them: Spain, Estonia, the United Kingdom, France, the Netherlands, Greece, Sweden, Germany, Italy, Norway, Bulgaria, Belgium and Denmark.  The 2012 Victims’ Rights Directive that entered into application in the Member States last month is the major general instrument on victims’ rights at EU level. It lays down a set of binding rights for all victims of crime, including rights to protection, support and assistance that take into account the individual needs of every victim of crime. It does not, however, provide the specific measures that would respond directly to the needs of victims of terrorism. Terrorist attacks leave behind individuals who have been injured, traumatised or lost their lives as a result of the attack. The victims of such attacks require specific protection, support and assistance that would respond to their specific needs related to the nature of this crime. That is why the Commission decided to introduce specific provisions on victims of terrorism to the proposal for a directive on combatting terrorism of 2 December. The main objective is to oblige the EU Member States to criminalise terrorist offences and offences related to terrorism such as travel and training for terrorist purposes and financing of terrorism without, however, forgetting about the victims of terrorism.  This proposal responds more precisely to the needs of victims of terrorism. In particular, the proposed directive requires Member States to ensure that victims of terrorism receive immediate access to professional specialist support services providing for physical and psycho-social treatment. Such support will be available for as long as necessary.  Terrorist attacks often result in chaos and disinformation, and access to reliable information for victims of terrorism and about victims of terrorism is therefore crucial. The proposed directive requires that the support services provide access to such reliable information. Under the proposed directive, the competent national authorities would be required to cooperate closely to ensure that all victims of terrorism are well informed and receive the necessary support and assistance, independently of where in the European Union they live. The tailored rules on protection, support and assistance to the victims of terrorism will add to the healing process of the victims and their families, and thus indirectly to the healing process of the whole society. This is also at the heart of our Radicalisation Awareness Network (RAN) Centre of Excellence connecting over 2 000 practitioners across the Union and supporting them in addressing radicalisation. The RAN Centre of Excellence, which became fully operational on 1 October this year, has been endowed with EUR 25 million for the next four years to empower practitioners on the ground. These practitioners come from different backgrounds, including representatives from local authorities, from the community and local police, prison and probation officers, social and health workers, teachers, civil society organisations, security officials and, last but not least, victims groups and associations. Victims of terrorism deserve our solidarity and support. They also have a very prominent role to play in countering radicalisation. Their testimonies can provide a crucial contribution in preventive work. Within the RAN, a specific working group on the remembrance of victims of terrorism has been set up. It will be instrumental in organising the 11 March Remembrance Day for the victims of terrorism in 2016. Since the Madrid bombings in 2004, the Commission has been commemorating the European Remembrance Day of victims of terrorism on 11 March exactly, and will continue to do so with the support of the RAN. The event will allow us to remember and honour those who have suffered and help the healing process of those who continue to suffer. Furthermore, with the help of the RAN we will make sure that the voices of the victims are heard and are openly and widely heard, especially among radicalised youth, as the stories and suffering of victims must never be in vain. These voices should make those individuals on the brink of extremism think twice before they act. I am particularly convinced of the important role victims can play in counter-narrative campaigns as well as, for example, in prison and probation. We will make sure that their experiences and stories can have a powerful but positive influence on individuals at risk or already radicalised.

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, it is very difficult to accept that anyone can be a victim. I had to accept it when the terrorist organization ETA murdered my brother and his wife. Since then, I have defended the rights of all victims. It doesn't matter if those who shoot do so on behalf of a so-called Islamic State or an independent Basque state. For me, there is no God or land worth the life of an innocent.  The Spanish Law on The Recognition and Comprehensive Protection of Victims of Terrorism says that victims should be recognized as a symbol of the democratic state's defence against the terrorist threat, and the Law in Spain refers not only to material measures, but also moral measures.  Terrorism strikes in all states of the Union. But not all states have laws to support victims; That is why a European Directive on the protection of victims of terrorism is indispensable. The needs of victims are summarized in four: the right to justice, truth, memory and dignity. And memory is very important, so that no one intends to make a terrorist a hero.  I take this opportunity to say that I still do not understand why the European People's Group is the only one proposing time and time again a Resolution on victims of terrorism, which continues to be rejected at the Conference of Presidents by all groups except the ECR. With this Resolution we just want to take a first step. Do the victims of terrorism not deserve a directive supported by Parliament, the Commission and the Council, which allows us to move from words and tears to deeds, which forces us to protect and help those most sacrificed for terrorism, who are the victims? Commissioner, when is a date for this directive?  (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: blue card question. - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support All my sympathies are with you, especially for the family tragedies you mentioned. I was a national representative for a long time in my country, Hungary, in a district where there were many victims and descendants of the Second World War. I'm talking about Nazi terror because there were victims of Nazi terror.  Would you do me the favor of telling your own party that you have the FIDESZ, which is led by a government this week trying to erect a statue of a man responsible for Nazi terror? Thank you!

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: "blue card" response. – We are talking here about victims of terrorism; we're not talking about war victims. But of course for me all the victims have to have the same support. All the victims, without exception.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the recent terrorist attacks have brought to attention a need which is not new, but which is of particular importance and urgency today.  Our attention must not only be paid to the perpetrators or potential perpetrators of the attacks for an effective repressive and preventive response, but also to the victims, direct or indirect. The Stockholm Programme of 2009 recognised the need to improve legislation and support measures for the protection of victims of crime, including, as a matter of priority, the victims of terrorism, a category which naturally includes the families of direct victims.  Directive 2012/29/EU on victims of crime also recognises that victims of terrorism, suffering the consequences of crimes aimed at harming society as a whole, need special attention and today, more than ever, the victims of terrorism must be able to count on solidarity and national and international support.  Appropriate measures need to be developed in this regard – as the Commissioner whom I thank for his report has pointed out today – but I believe that there is still something more to be envisaged. There is an immediate need for free medical, psychological, social and material assistance. Long-term assistance is needed, both for those who have suffered direct physical or mental damage as a result of terrorist acts and, where necessary, for their families. We need effective access to justice, including the possibility of legal aid and adequate compensation and compensation for the damage suffered, and it is also important to recognise and support the role of victim protection associations.

name: Timothy KIRKHOPE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, our loss, our grief and our anger at the atrocities we have witnessed at the hands of terrorists in this past year have struck deep into the consciousness of who we are as nations, as communities and as a Union. At times, our fear and our grief force us to question afresh who we trust, what we know and what we believe. But we must never allow the hateful rhetoric of the few to make victims of us all, as we are a Europe of democracy, diversity and liberty. In the days that followed Paris, the feelings that echoed throughout France and Europe were of sadness and shock. But then came the more powerful message of resilience and of hope. The bigotry and barbarity of ISIL must never make victims of tolerance and cohesion. We must do all we can to help those that survive these atrocities rebuild their lives and feel safe again. We must supply the security needed to our citizens to allow them to live lives of freedom. We will defeat the enemy and with that our lives will become free from fear, but not at the price of the tolerance of religions and cultures which have contributed to the Europe of today.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, conventional criminals do not usually seek general publicity of their crimes. They don't usually consider themselves heroes for killing. They try to evade the action of justice and not be known.  Terrorism offences are different. When committed in democratic societies like ours, they are very serious crimes that attack men, women, children and the elderly, pursuing, twisting, mutilating or murdering them. But in addition to destroying them and their families, they seek the propaganda effect. Some are wanted to terrorize all, to achieve political goals illegitimately, even to weaken countries. Right now, jihadist terrorism seeks to do us as much damage as possible and weaken our democracy.  Terrorism offences are eminently public crimes. Killers are often considered victims and heroes. They are victims, and their victims are stigmatized and then humiliated when these killers and their environments have the capacity for social control.  The mourning of the victims of terrorism therefore has a dual nature: a private, human nature, which requires attention and help because it devastates the environments, because it leaves a part of the relatives of the people atrociously murdered adrift; and a public, political nature, in the sense that in democratic societies it is the freedoms of all that terrorists attack.  Therefore, justice, truth, memory—which includes the fight against denierism or any other form of indecent rhetoric—are essential. No one will dare support impunity against crimes of rape or murder of children or women. But if those children or women are killed by terrorists, there will be those who at some point ask for impunity for terrorist killers out of collusion or fear.  There are villages in my country where murderers and people involved in terrorist killings are honored and where terrorist killers are proud to have killed. It is intolerable and that must have social and criminal reproach. Because terrorism continues to cause suffering to the victims, to their dignity, to the possibility of performing a duel without consequences each new attack because then the murderers with the right to kill continue to re-claim. And this doesn't close the duels. I have met hundreds of victims of different types of terrorism in Spain and I believe that the European Parliament has not developed its full potential to care for the victims of terrorism. A specific directive would be very, very appropriate.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, in the wake of the devastating terrorist atrocities inflicted on the world in recent months and years, I convey my utmost sympathy to all of the victims and to their families. Da’esh is a Frankenstein monster, and Member States must stop bankrolling it. Stopping Da’esh means stopping European banks from accepting revenue from the USD 2 million per day Da’esh gains from its control of oil fields.  Member States must act with humanity. They must address the needs of the millions of victims who have become refugees as a result of the terror that they are enduring. Violent extremism has grown in places ravaged by Western militaries, making the world considerably more dangerous. Efforts to de-escalate the situation in Syria and pursue a model of conflict resolution are what we need. Dropping more bombs in Syria is not the solution. The recent conflict in Ireland saw the British state apparatus kill with impunity. The Council of Europe Human Rights Commissioner, Nils Muižnieks, says that there has been virtual impunity for British state actors. Unfortunately, in these debates state-sponsored terrorism is often neglected. Reports from Iraq and Libya – and now Syria – demand that this Parliament end the double standards and condemn all acts of terrorism. As a Member State and signatory of the European Convention of Human Rights, the British Government has failed to deal with its Article 2 obligation: the right to life.

text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I believe that we have all been shocked by the victims of the recent terrorist attacks in Paris. I believe, however, that the main interest of these victims is that we should gather the facts that we have at our disposal to provide such protection for the future, and not fuel an emotional debate and an emotional reaction on the backs of victims of terrorist attacks. This applies both to the question of the causes of terrorism, which, if you take a closer look, are in the current crisis in the Middle East and in the wars that are still taking place there and which we must resolve together as the European Union, but also to the fact that many of these terrorist assassins have been radicalised in Europe, especially in prisons. We need to work to put an end to this and actually curb this radicalisation.  Then it is a question of looking at the facts: what creates security? I believe that it has become clear that we need better cooperation between the European authorities, we need better exchange of information and not unprompted monitoring of all citizens. Nor is this in line with the freedoms that we are defending here against such terrorists.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the first duty of any government is the protection of its own citizens, and it is often said that terrorists can never win; but this is not true. Terrorists can win when a sizable number of the general population sympathise with their long-term objectives. For example, in the United Kingdom, the IRA terrorised and murdered its way into government in Northern Ireland. Few would be publicly prepared to admit to supporting the terrorism of the IRA, but plenty are willing to vote for Sinn Féin, its political wing. The current terrorist threat comes from Islamic fundamentalists who want to establish a world caliphate under Sharia law. We are told that the vast majority of Muslims are peace-loving and non-violent, and I accept that is true. But the majority are not the problem, the minority are; and they all follow the same religion. The teachings of that religion, if taken literally, are totally incompatible with democracy and Western civilisation.  We face a massive problem in combating fundamentalist ideology in our societies. Last month I said here that the first step in doing that was to stop, once and for all, all further mass immigration from Islamic countries. The EU’s policy to allow millions more migrants from Islamic countries is nothing short of playing Russian roulette with the lives of our citizens.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, the point of order is under Rule 11(2), which is on Members’ conduct being characterised by mutual respect. As a Sinn Féin member and someone who topped the poll in the north of Ireland with almost 160 000 people voting for me, I find it absolutely disgraceful that someone in this Chamber would try to make the connection that the previous speaker did. The voters of Sinn Féin vote for us based on our mandate, based on what we put forward to tell the people how we will represent them, and based on the manifesto that we present to them. That is why the thousands – almost half a million people – on the island of Ireland vote for Sinn Féin, so I think that based on Rule 11(2) the Member should conduct himself in a manner characterised by mutual respect. That was not what we heard from the Member here this evening.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). Mr President, the Commission is telling us today that it is seeking to provide protection and support to victims of terrorist attacks. We must ease the suffering of victims and their families, we must avoid the heroism of terrorists, and the truth must be brought out and remembrance days must be established for the victims. Unfortunately, some countries of the Union have different criteria regarding terrorist attacks, depending on the identity of the victims and perpetrators and, above all, on their ideological beliefs. The Greek state refuses to recognise and provide any form of support to victims of terrorist attacks when the victims are Greek nationalists. In the dozens of terrorist attacks that have taken place against our movement, of the People's Association "Golden Dawn", culminating in the cowardly and cold-blooded murder of two of our members, my son, Giorgos Foudoulis and Manolis Kapelonis and the very serious injury of Alexander Elder, the state not only did not stand up to the victims and their families, as it should, in accordance with European Directive 2012/29/EU, but on the contrary, put forward and continues to put forward obstacles, ignore and hinder. I denounce that in over eighty attacks not a single arrest has ever been made. It will therefore be good, since the Commission is really interested in victims, to ensure that the rules are protected and respected in all states, regardless of their ideology.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: PPE). Mr President, I am pleased that all the political groups agree that Directive 2012/29/EU cannot cover victims of terrorism since it concerns victims of crime. Terrorism is a crime against humanity and a tangible threat to the European Union. Victims and their families require special arrangements, need recognition and respect for their rights, need social, economic, political, psychological and legal support. Whether they are false revolutionarys who strike at the institutions of democracy, such as justice, parliament, entrepreneurship, troops and the state - as was the case with "November 17th" that has marginalised my country for 30 years, or are paranoids possessed by religious ideology, such as those of ISIS, the perpetrators of terrorist acts create victims, blood, pain and panic. Their victims have rights to defend which special regulation is needed and required. Ladies and gentlemen, the European Union's response to terrorism must come through more democracy. The answer to terrorism must be given without fear and panic. Shielding the victims, the heroes of this case, requires an answer based on respect for democratic norms.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the 13 November attacks in Paris have shaken Europe, but before that of Charlie Hebdo this year, and those in London in 2006, and those in Spain – the terrible massacre of 2004.  I too speak Spanish and represent, in this European Parliament, a Spanish society that has been sneered against ETA's counter-terrorism decades until its defeat.  And, therefore, I am also speaking on behalf of a party – the Socialist Party – which bet, throughout this fight against terrorism, in the opposition and in the Government, to place out of the debate between political parties the fight against terrorism and also the commitment to victims, for dignity, for memory, for justice and for the truth , for the reparation of the victims.  And that is why I too want to bet on a special directive which complements that adopted in October 2012 and which does not sufficiently honour the speciality and uniqueness of the drama of victims of terrorism with regard to the measures they require: health and psychological, labour and social integration, the protection of their legal assistance and their special position in the processes that concern them.  And that is why I am convinced that a special directive would contribute to this unique reparation that the victims of terrorism deserve also at European level, since my conviction that, when terrorists hit victims, they are not only seeking their blood and the pain of their families, but intimidating and terrorizing all Democrats, and that the more we protect victims across Europe , the stronger democracy and the rule of law will be across Europe.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: – I would like to take the opportunity to call for a little extra attention for vulnerable victims of terror, such as people with disabilities. Member States should ensure that the victim is properly assisted at first contact and any further contacts with the police or justice system, if they need support in understanding or understanding. This means, in concrete terms, that a deaf person must be able to count on the assistance of a sign language interpreter at the police station or the court. A person with a mental disability should be able to bring a confidant. Only then can he fully exercise his rights as a victim.  This is and remains a major pain point in the many EU countries. There is therefore a need for awareness and follow-up. Therefore, the right to understand and be understood should be an important focus for the Commission in the preparation of the implementation report.

name: James NICHOLSON
text: – Mr President, my sympathies go out to all those who have suffered at the hands of terrorists across Europe and beyond, especially in my own constituency in Northern Ireland for over 40 years. Historically, terrorists have not worked in isolation, but have shared expertise, knowhow and equipment between their groups. It is therefore only right that we share best practice in protecting and supporting the needs of innocent victims and survivors of terrorism. Innocent victims and survivors of terrorism need support long after the media spotlight has shifted elsewhere. In my constituency, many individuals, families and communities continue to bear the physical and emotional scars associated with decades of terrorism. The needs of innocent victims and survivors are complex and evolve over time. Innocent victims and survivors have the right to truth and justice. They also have the right not to be retraumatised by terrorists seeking to glory in their acts of terror. In closing, we must clarify and clearly differentiate between innocent victims and perpetrators. Those who have sought to maim and murder are not victims. I support the victims, not the victim-makers.

name: Brian HAYES
text: – Mr President, I welcome this proposal and I want to congratulate my colleague Teresa for her work in highlighting the need of victims right the way across our society. As others have said, we have a responsibility to help those people who are innocent victims of terrorism, right the way across the 28 Member States of the European Union.  In our own country in Ireland, we were subjected for over 35 years to an illegal, criminal campaign by the IRA and other organisations which killed people, intimidated people, criminalised people, and especially ensured that the proceeds of their activity in crime were put underground and used for other alleged activity. The point is this: we have a responsibility to support people who are dealing with their injuries and who are dealing with bereavement. In the circumstances where our country, especially, has gone through a transformative process as a result of the reconciliation – the peace agreement – we need to do much more now.  I call on the Commission to see within six months whether or not all Member States of the European Union have transposed the legislation that this House passed, and I call on the Commission to name those Member States where much more needs to be done.

text: – Mr President, I do not want to ask Mr Nicholson anything. I simply want you to give me a second to remember, in this debate on the victims, the victims who died two days ago in an attack on the Spanish embassy in Kabul. As European victims, I believe that these two policemen at the Spanish embassy in Kabul city deserve to be remembered in this debate on victims of terrorism.

The implementation of relevant Directive 2012/29/EU in the Member States of the European Union opens up a first area of protection for victims of terrorism. But that is not enough. text: – Mr President, the global terrorist threat, the peculiarities of the actions it commits, the typology and number of those affected by such attacks and their significance force us or to supplement the Victims Directive or to develop a specific rule for victims of global terrorism, because we are facing a phenomenon that is new and different from what has been known to this day : facts that require a minimum standard of care at European level, a basis that facilitates the visibility and accessibility of citizens to these programmes, limits the bureaucratic burden on users in multi-level and multidisciplinary delivery situations, ensures the sustainability of assistance and assumes the transnational dimension of the problem.  Victims need empathy, humanity and understanding, but also effectiveness and services throughout the European Union.  We have to fight terrorists and their crimes from democracy, from intelligence, but we are also obliged to protect first-person victims, by sheer chance, the attack with which totalitarianism wants to destroy our freedom, our values and our ways of life.

text: – Unfortunately, in recent times, rather than with positive content, such as how to secure more jobs and how to offer a better future for our young people, we must increasingly deal more and more with the prevention of terrorism and the elimination of the consequences it brings. When an attack happens, we're all shocked. Of course, we hope that the measures we are ingly will be effective and that we can prevent attacks, but the reality is different. They're victims. And all those who survive a terrorist attack and their relatives are marked for life.  It is very important that we are aware of this, and that is why we must do everything possible – first of all, to prevent attacks from occuring, then we must step forward and minimise the consequences, provide all assistance, together with all organisations, both financially and legally and mentally, for the victims and their families.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Mr. President, Europe is unequivocally a continent of tolerance, but unfortunately Europe is unequivocal and a continent with a long history of terrorism. Let's think of the Red Brigades, the Baader-Meinhof group, ETA, the IRA and all those terrorist attacks we recently had in Madrid, London, now paris. It's all a history of terrorism on The Soil of Europe.  And that is why this directive is much needed. We really need to show maximum solidarity with the victims, including the complete system, both from the European level to the local level, because that is the only way to really help the victims, because they live everywhere in a city, in a place.  The inclusion of social welfare, the involvement of NGOs, the inclusion of the health system, the inclusion of all those who can help victims through such a directive is definitely welcome and that is why I support these intentions that the Commission has at the moment.

text: – The twentieth century was marked by a whole range of totalitarian systems. Europe, where there were huge numbers of casualties, and many of them were not simply recognised for the rights and status of victims. The second half of the twentieth century was marked by political groups that, in a special way – in Spain and Ireland, Italy, Greece – had their own political struggle and left behind a whole host of victims. Now we are facing mass terrorism, where virtually no one knows when, where terrorism that opposes social regulation will be struck, opposes the social arrangements and policies of individual countries, and therefore leaves behind a whole host of victims. I support what my colleague has prepared today. That is to say, the proposal to draw up a directive and, in this way, to focus on the victims left behind by terrorism and, on the other hand, to prevent the reasons why terrorism is even occurs.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for all their valuable remarks. I will pass the general spirit of this debate to Commissioner Jourová, but let me conclude with a few things. The Commission is very much committed to countering terrorism and radicalisation. I am particularly grateful to Parliament for its report on the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations, adopted just a few weeks ago. I think that the very close cooperation between all of the actors at different levels – national and local – is very much crucial, and we should encourage greater cooperation between actors on the ground, including in support of victims of terrorism and their families. The Commission recognises the different situations of the victims of terrorism and the victims of general and other crimes, and that is why we proposed the new directive that I was talking about, which includes support for victims of terrorism and their families. The Commission counts very much on support from Parliament for a swift adoption of the proposed directive on combating terrorism. I will also pass the message to Commissioner Jourová on your request for checking the timing for the implementation of this directive.

We have always known throughout this history of counter-terrorism, in opposition and in government, to put the fight against terrorism out of the debate between political parties. Also for the commitment to the victims. For dignity. By memory. For justice. For the truth. For repairing the pain caused to the whole society. And that is why I too would like to bet from the European Parliament on a special European Directive supplementing that adopted in October 2012 — Directive 29/12 on the protection of victims of serious crimes — since it does not yet, or sufficiently cover, honour the speciality and uniqueness of the drama of victims of terrorism.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on Bart Staes' motion for a resolution, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the objection in accordance with Article 106: authorisation of genetically modified maize NK603xT25 (2015/3019 (RSP)) (B8-1365/2015)

name: Bart STAES
text: Rapporteur. – The Committee on the Environment adopted a resolution on 1 December to object to the placing on the market and introduction of a particular maize type of Monsanto, nk603 and T25. We ask the Commission not to grant this authorisation. This is done in the context of the debate on democratising the decision-making process around GMOs. This is also the case in the context of the debate on the safety of certain chemicals, in particular gluphosinate and glyphosate, two pesticides which cause resistance in the GMO concerned. The European Parliament has therefore initiated this debate today, at the first time that was possible after the vote in the Committee on the Environment. This was the earliest time to be able to debate it in plenary. And what do we notice? The Commission decided on 4 December, three days after the Committee on the Environment to object and before this plenary debate, to allow this GMO.  Commissioner, you should send the message to your colleague Andriukaitis: this commission's behaviour is indecent. It's a provocation. It is a complete disregard for the political statements of the European Parliament and, in fact, this is also very damaging to the mutual relationship between the Commission and Parliament. Ladies and gentlemen, I do not think we can just let this get over us. We are further away than ever from the promises made by President Juncker on 15 July 2014 and from the political directives put forward, announcing that the Commission would no longer take decisions on GMOs against a majority of Member States. We are further away from that debate than ever before.  The Commission has made an attempt to introduce new legislation on the import of GMOs. We made that proposal on 28 October 2004. and asked the Commission to come up with a new proposal, but the Commission refuses. In the meantime, the Commission is continuing to allow imports of GMO plants into the European Union. In 2015, more than ever before, this type of GMOs were allowed.  Furthermore, of course, this debate is also about the transparency of decision-making in the Commission. I have used the Public Administration Act to find out how the Commission's proposal came about. I got a thick pack of paper, in which all kinds of things are blackened. I call this undemocratic, not transparent. So, Commissioner, I would like to ask you that the 12 options that the Commission had in front of us to achieve greater democratisation of legislation should be passed on to us. I think that would be disrespectful.  Secondly, the public health issue. The GMO concerned that you have now admitted is resistant to pesticide gluphosinate, a highly toxic chemical, and glyphosate. This is in the context of the discussion in which the International Agency for Research on Cancer has said that this substance is probably carcinogenic. EFSA says that is not the case. A letter has been sent from 96 scientists undermining efsa's methods. They say that this has not been done correctly and, in this context, you, the Commission, allow you, Commissioner, a substance that is resistant to these substances and which at least has debate. So, Commissioner, I would like to ask you: answer our questions, withdraw that permit and make sure that we have the options to legislate reasonably and, ladies and gentlemen, let us show that we are not intimidated by the Commission, let us adopt this resolution of the Committee on the Environment on Wednesday.

name: Bart STAES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for giving the Commission the opportunity to react to this draft motion for a resolution on the implementing decision of the Commission authorising the placing on the market of genetically modified maize NK603xT25 for food and feed. First of all, I would like to recall that the European regulatory system for GMOs is among the strictest worldwide. It was adopted and agreed by the European Parliament as the co-legislator. The decision on authorisation that you will discuss today, as with all other decisions on the authorisation of GMOs for food and feed use, is adopted in accordance with the so-called examination procedure set out in Regulation No 182/2011 on comitology. Under this procedure, I acknowledge that the European Parliament has a right of scrutiny concerning the question of whether the draft authorisation exceeds the implementing powers granted to the Commission. From our point of view, this is not the case and I will try to explain why. This regulation provides that decisions on the authorisation of GMOs for food and feed use are adopted by the Commission following several procedural steps. Therefore, allow me to clarify that these steps have been followed for the decision on the authorisation of the aforementioned maize. The application for authorisation to place this GMO on the EU market was submitted in 2010. The European Food Safety Authority performed a comprehensive risk management of this product. This was based on the highest scientific standards, taking into account the positive expert opinions already granted separately for NK602 and T25, both of which are authorised in the EU. In July 2015, EFSA published a favourable opinion which concluded that GM maize NK603xT25 is safe for human and animal health and for the environment. Member States, of course, were able to comment on the risk assessment, and EFSA has addressed all their comments in its final opinion. The public also commented on the EFSA opinion, and all of the scientific comments which were received were scrutinised by EFSA. Based on the positive EFSA opinion, the Commission submitted a draft implementing decision for the authorisation of this GMO to a vote of the standing committee on 19 October 2015. The Member States did not reach a qualified majority against or in favour of this draft decision. In accordance with the comitology rules and the GMO legislation, the Commission proposed the draft decision of authorisation to the appeal committee on 10 November 2015. Again, the Member States did not reach a qualified majority in favour or against.  All these procedural steps followed by the Commission are fully in line with the existing legislation. Therefore, I hope you will appreciate that the Commission did not exceed its implementing powers, as it endeavoured to explain to members of the Environment and Public Health Committee on 1 December 2015. Consequently, the Commission continued to proceed with the draft authorisation decisions for maize NK603xT25 and adopted it on 4 December 2015.

name: Renate SOMMER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her It is now 16 years since I, as rapporteur for my group, negotiated the so-called Release Directive, which regulates the authorisation and cultivation of GMOs in the European Union, during the conciliation procedure. name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, we are looking at a beautiful example of the interests of the European Commission and already now also of the kind of democracy that prevails in the institutions of the European Union. In addition to its undemocratic contours, the concrete content of the decision also takes on the greatest gravity. text: – The European Commission's decision authorising a new genetically modified maize variety is another example of arrogance. I draw your attention to the fact that the aforementioned maize variety is a hybrid of previously authorised variety 603 , which is infamous for research by the French scientist Seralini. It found that this GMO in laboratory mice caused multiple ailments and tumors. Attempts were made to refute the findings of this investigation. The European Food Safety Agency has also contributed to the wave of criticism. However, in two Courts of Paris, on 6 and 26 November, the scientist defended his honour. The European Commission should therefore take more seriously the potential risks to human and animal health of these GMOs. I support this European Parliament resolution and call on the Commission to finally start working with it, not before Parliament.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all let me say that I will of course transmit all your remarks and all your concerns to Commissioner Andriukaitis to allow him to respond in detail to your questions. Allow me now to react to some of the comments made. Firstly, many of you referred to the commitment that was made by President Juncker. Let me remind you that the commitment was to review the decision-making process for GMOs in order to give more possibilities to Member States to express their views and take into account the concerns of their citizens. The commitment was met with proposals that give legal capacity to the Member States concerning the use of EU-authorised genetically-modified food and feed on their territory based on national reasons unrelated to risks to health and the environment.  Your draft resolution makes reference to the decision of the European Parliament on 28 October 2015 to reject these legislative proposals. The Commission regrets the decision of the European Parliament, because the Commission believes that this legislative proposal would enable Member States to address, at national level, considerations which are not covered by the EU decision-making process. The Commission, therefore, maintained this proposal, which should be discussed in the Council at the beginning of 2016 as the next step in the ordinary legislative procedure.  As a second point, I want to say that the Commission is aware of your concerns as regards the herbicide glyphosate. I would like to recall that the approval of active substances for plant protection products, such as glyphosate, and the setting of maximum residue levels for herbicides in food and feed products are not regulated by GMO legislation, but by the Regulation on Pesticides and Maximum Residue Levels. The review procedure for glyphosate is ongoing. Please be reassured that your concerns are duly noted in this regard. As regards the request in the resolution to suspend GMO authorisation until the authorisation process is reviewed, allow me to stress that the Commission has indeed reviewed the authorisation process. It has consequently proposed to amend the GMO legislation. The proposal is in codecision procedure, and, as usual, the rules in place continue to apply during the negotiations between the co-legislators and until a final agreement is reached. The Commission can therefore only proceed with the GM food and feed application in compliance with the existing legal framework.  In conclusion, let me call on you not to adopt this motion for a resolution. As I have tried to explain, the Commission has fulfilled its duty without exceeding the implementing powers when authorising genetically modified maize NK603xT25.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on the Sven Schulze report, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on the implementation of the European Microfinance Instrument Progress (2015/2042(INI) (A8-0331/2015)).

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs and also the Commission for the really good cooperation on this report in recent months. We have had constructive cooperation, several shadow rapporteur meetings, and we have been able to negotiate viable compromises, which also found a broad majority in committee. I expect the same for the report here in plenary. What is this report really about? It was a matter of reviewing the implementation of the Progress microfinancial instrument halfway through its term on how effectively and sustainably new livelihoods can be created by giving unemployed and disadvantaged people access to loans that they would not otherwise have because of their social situation.  However, it was also a question of investigating whether there were any omissions in this instrument. What is the Progress financial instrument? It was launched in 2010 with a volume of 205 million euros, initially financed by the Progress programme of the same name. Since 2013, there has been a new financial basis called EaSI, which is the instrument for work and social innovation.  Progress' financial support allows lenders to lend more to people at higher risk of default through broader refinancing. We have seen a low default risk of up to 5%. The Progress microfinancial instrument is now available in 22 out of 28 Member States, and soon there will be 23 with Croatia.   What have we been able to find? Progress is a functioning social policy instrument and makes a difference – especially in the times of the financial crisis. This is confirmed by the European Court of Auditors' investigation this year.  It helps to achieve the employment objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, because most jobs are ultimately created in micro-enterprises, and that is where the instrument starts. It supports the building of existence and the preservation of existence. This is underpinned by the high number of micro-credits. Progress is beneficial for the European taxpayer and is socially valuable. Unemployed people get a chance and can set up a business that pays taxes and creates employment. This is cheaper than paying out transfers.  The lending requirements were almost met. 13 252 micro-credits with a volume of EUR 124.6 million were granted, slightly less than the target of EUR 142.4 million.  As far as the target groups are concerned, we have seen the following: some colleagues wanted to broaden the number of beneficiaries, which others found problematic, given the small financial resources of only EUR 205 million. In my view, a viable middle ground has been found here.  The female quota is pleasingly high: 37% of the beneficiaries are women entrepreneurs. As a result, Progress does not quite meet the 40% target. In future, we would like to see a balanced rate of 50% men and 50% women.  Less well-favoured groups and minorities were reached. We also found that indicators developed for data collection were often inappropriate and insufficiently detailed, and that we do not know enough about the needs and survival rates of micro-enterprises. We have also found that social economy companies have been less well served with credit. The problem has already been detected. Under EaSI, the financial allocation of social enterprises has been significantly improved. However, for these companies, the specific programme of credit intermediaries is now lacking. I am now looking forward to the debate and will comment again afterwards.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Sven Schulze, for his report, which stresses the importance of adequate access to, and the availability of, finance with a direct impact on Europe’s 2020 targets, fostering employment and fighting poverty and social exclusion. Our ambition, as highlighted several times by President Juncker, is to create quality jobs and get Europe growing again. Microfinance is an important tool to promote entrepreneurship and help Europe get back on the path to growth and, ultimately, to reduce social and financial exclusion. I therefore welcome this report, which sheds light on the European Progress Microfinance Facility’s achievements in making entrepreneurship an option for all, including vulnerable persons and those who would be otherwise financially excluded.  To promote the potential of microfinance for enabling entrepreneurship, on 19 October this year my colleague, Commissioner Thyssen, opened the first European Microfinance Day in Brussels, together with the Luxembourg Presidency and representatives of the European Investment Bank, the European Parliament and the European Economic and Social Committee. Your report rightly highlights that the Facility has substantially contributed to job preservation and, if I may add, to job creation with over 60 000 jobs created or maintained thanks to this Facility. In addition, half of micro-borrowers reported an increase in their turnover thanks to the microloans made possible by this Facility. The relevance of the Facility to enabling unemployed and disadvantaged people to gain access to finance, especially in times of crisis, is well underlined in your report. Indeed, Progress microfinance has a track record of successful outreach to such vulnerable groups. A recently published report by the European Court of Auditors assisting the Facility’s intervention in microfinance concluded that thanks to the use of financial instruments it has adequately addressed the needs of micro-entrepreneurs. Moreover, the financial instruments under the successor EU programme for Employment and Social Innovation (EaSI) could also play an important role in addressing some of the challenges posed by the intensifying refugee influx. Your report precisely points to the fact that while Progress microfinance can be considered successful as a whole, there is room for improvement. Indeed, these improvements, such as greater outreach to target vulnerable groups and improved social impact reporting, combined with technical assistance and dedicated support for capacity-building of microcredit providers and increased complementarity with other instruments, have been taken into account in the design of the successor Employment and Social Innovation programme, as well as specific support for social enterprises, which is a priority objective of the Commission.  The EaSI Programme is making EUR 193 million available until 2020. This includes EUR 96 million in guarantees which can leverage more than EUR 500 million to micro and social entrepreneurs. Moreover, I would like to stress that the EaSI Regulation already includes a definition of ‘social enterprise’. Therefore, it would be advisable to stick to this definition. In addition to guarantees and funded instruments, EaSI financial instruments will offer funding for capacity building. This will help microcredit providers develop their business and better channel much—needed funds to the most excluded clients, which are often hard to reach. I am very pleased to announce that the recently launched guarantee scheme, with about EUR 90 million for microfinance and social entrepreneurship, has made a very promising start. In four months, the European Investment Fund, which manages the scheme, has received over 30 applications, accounting for approximately half of the total budget. In conclusion, I welcome the report’s recommendation that the Progress Microfinance Facility should be continued. However, as you know, the investment period under this instrument draws to a close in April 2016. The Commission is confident that the EaSI Programme will build upon the success of Progress Microfinance. It will continue and expand activity in this area and deliver on the improvements highlighted by honourable Members in their findings on the Progress programme, thus bringing even better results in the fight against social and financial exclusion and opening up routes to good employment.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: rapporteur of the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his report and say that, from the Committee on Budgetary Control, we have seen some problems in a programme which appeared as a pilot project in 2010 in the midst of the crisis and has been absolutely essential, and for which we call for the maintenance and increase of financial coverage.  But it has, in principle, some problems, such as limited geographic coverage. We would like to know and for the Commission to tell us why only 22 or 23 of the 28 Member States are interested in this project and are asking for it. There are also too many rejections, almost 2,000 for over-indebtedness of individuals and businesses, which we should be able to improve. We would need more information and a better assessment of the needs of micro-entrepreneurs, as well as why the many rejections.  As for the viability of micro-enterprises, 44% do not last more than a year, and it is true that we do not want to work on quantity, but we believe that it would be very important if the project also addressed the quality of employment created through these micro-enterprises and that we should also work with the associations of persons with disabilities or people in marginal or troubled situations. Of course, these are also projects where women still have a greater presence since they have undoubtedly been the most affected by the crisis, and we would like to see in some way strengthened and recognised, within the European Commission and the institutions, the status of micro-entrepreneur, with all those recognitions given to other types of companies that are much more indebted and that , however, they are suppressing employment.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the Commission for your – Micro-credits are not only important for developing countries, they are also a key part of starting businesses in developed Europe. Microfinance also makes an important contribution to the realisation of the Europe 2020 strategy, and the PROGRESS financial instrument is crucial for that part of our economy that has been most affected by the situation in which we live. I would like to thank my colleague Sven for his good and critical assessment of the implementation of PROGRESS and also gave the guidelines in the report for the continuation of the implementation of this programme. I think it is very important that we think carefully and clearly define who micro-enterprises are and what microfinance is. This is precisely what we have most problems with: micro-enterprises are very vulnerable and they are not small and medium-sized enterprises. We need to separate this well so that we know where we are going from PROGRESS. And one last thing. I consider it very important that micro-enterprises also have a place in the European Fund for Strategic Investments. For? Because 85% of new jobs are created precisely in micro-enterprises.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, Commissioner, today we are discussing the voice and opinion given by the European Parliament on the implementation of an important microcredit instrument, the Progress, which we will vote on tomorrow, which was partially replaced in 2014 and will be totally replaced in spring 2016 by the European Programme for Employment and Social Innovation. This has also been a technical and political challenge for this Parliament.  We have been working since the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, which has also wanted to give its opinion because we believe – and this is the key issue for us – that credit has not only an economic object in society, but also a social role, and especially a programme like this that tries to reach people outside the natural financial market. That's why we've driven a number of opinions.  Firstly, the need to continue the microcredit market by strengthening the figure of intermediaries , and especially non-bank intermediaries , in order to maximiate the possibilities of financing all kinds of projects, especially vulnerable people, discussed here today , unemployed people, people with disabilities and some new phenomena, to which the Commissioner referred, such as that of the refugees we have had this year.  Solve the implementation problems detected in the Progress instrument through the new program that replaces it; encourage the creation of opportunities for self-employment and quality job creation among the unemployed, especially since we know that unemployment is a major problem on the continent; urge the Commission to rigorously assess the attainment of these social objects; expand access to microcredits, especially businesses in the social economy; and encourage respect and compliance with the code of good practice for this type of activity.  So, let's learn from mistakes, especially knowing that there are people behind each of these credits.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Madam President, the European Progress Microfinance Mechanism aims to facilitate the establishment and support of small businesses in order to boost employment in the Member States of the Union. Since 2010, it has focused on supporting the long-term unemployed and, in general, the economically weaker, by granting microcredit of less than EUR 25 000, for the establishment and expansion of small enterprises. However, the Progress Mechanism set up to combat poverty, by strengthening entrepreneurship, has finally simply evolved into a profitable banking industry.  Moreover, this microfinance, combined with the European Union's 2016 funds for financial support, is not sufficient to boost employment, especially in impoverished Greece with its one and a half million unemployed and the thousands of small businesses that have closed. The funds for the Progress Mechanism should therefore be increased for both Greece and the other Member States of the European Union.

name: Renate WEBER
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I want to start by saying how much I appreciate this instrument. I had the chance to speak to several beneficiaries from my own country, Romania, as well as from Belgium, Bulgaria and the Netherlands. I saw how with a little money at the right time, and with dedication, people’s lives can change for themselves and also for their employees. Such instruments are the right answer to the question: what kind of help do people need? Most of them do not need and do not want state assistance, but rather want to be empowered to manage their own lives. The European Parliament has been calling for such an instrument since 2008, by means of its own-initiative resolution. When the microfinance facility was eventually established in 2010, it was conceived in response to the worsening credit market in the European Union and in order to reach the goals of the EU 2020 strategy on growth and jobs. However, even if overall the microfinance facility can take credit for making finance more accessible and for contributing to job preservation and job creation, there was relatively little focus on vulnerable groups. This is one field in which I hope that we will do better in the future. I cannot but hope that the instrument which will replace it from 2016, EaSI, will take into consideration our recommendations. And maybe other similar instruments should be set up to empower more categories of people: those who – as revealed by the evaluation – belong to an unprofitable target group like the young, unemployed or self-employed, immigrant minorities and disabled. After all, the economic incentives should go hand in hand with social inclusion measures.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, just as when we discussed the design of this programme, we value and are responsible for strengthening this microfinance mechanism. It is clear today that, even with regard to the possibilities already existing, the potential of this programme is not properly exploited. This is largely due to a common problem in EU programmes: the lack of information and ways to support stakeholders. Often, it is those who are less excluded, those who hold the information, who end up benefiting from this possibility of applying for microcredit.  We follow the logic of the report that does not emphasize the solution of microfinance as an absolute solution to solve social and economic problems, as many emphasize. This logic is fallacious and dangerous, puts social equity and development policies in the hands of the greatest or lesser success of individuals, without holding states from their functions accountable. Microfinance yes, but without replacing the social functions of states.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank and congratulate the rapporteur for his thorough review of the implementation of the Progress Microfinance Facility, which was created to build on the positive impact that micro-loans have on local economies in developing countries, and has been seen to be successful across European countries as well.  It is not built to directly finance micro-enterprise, but allows providers or intermediaries to increase their lending. It has helped those they support to realise their potential as entrepreneurs, to develop new skills through training and monitoring and to find jobs. It is aimed at target groups: the unemployed, those claiming social benefits, immigrants – people who cannot get conventional bank loans. It is primarily a socio-political instrument, providing loans of up to EUR 25 000. As we know, the best social policy that one can give is the opportunity to help people to help themselves – to give them a leg-up, rather than a hand-out. Entrepreneurship gives people meaning, allowing them a stake in their own community, and that filters through in the value that it provides in terms of job creation, confidence and certainly vibrancy in that community. There have been a number of comments raised in the report. While the implementation of the Facility has been successful, nonetheless there are areas where it can be improved. In the area of women’s entrepreneurship, we need to ensure we look at best practice and encourage sharing of experiences and, of course, youth entrepreneurship. I very much look forward to the next step in this progress, the Social Innovation Programme in April 2016, and I look forward to the Commissioner’s contribution in that area.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, I would like to express my agreement with the report and its structure, especially since we are faced with a commitment, that of broadening the horizon of Progress, because there is no doubt that the social enterprise system generates well-being and work within a framework that favours particularly vulnerable workers, but is also able to put to good use the ability to do business. , especially for women and young people.  Therefore, the microfinance tool must be strengthened, also through its simplification with an information and tutoring strategy capable of expanding the audience, but also of evaluating its sustainability and employability. The social economy today is undoubtedly an extraordinary lever of new and good employment capable of meeting the challenges of the market. Microfinance can give space and visibility to the social enterprise system for a welfare that we want more and more generative.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I listened very carefully to what the Commissioner and my colleagues had to say, and I am very pleased overall. I remember being here in plenary five or six years ago when this was being discussed, and many Members were making the point that, due to the financial crisis, in particular young entrepreneurs and female entrepreneurs could not get the money needed to start up. It is great that this has been such a success. As the Commissioner pointed out, there has been only a 5% drop-out and, particularly, a figure of 37% women – even though the target was 40% – and they hope to move to 50-50. That is very encouraging indeed.  She also mentioned the review in 2016, and hopefully this will continue. It has to continue, because it has been a success. We need to hear more about the successes in Europe rather than the criticisms we hear of our failings.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: – Madam President, it is right that we focus on small business, which in my country is creating three times more jobs than big listed companies. But I want to back tonight paragraph 30 of the report, which regrets the lack of funding to social enterprises and calls for more help for social entrepreneurs. According to Social Enterprise East of England, over half of our social enterprises are less than five years old, and nearly one in seven export – precisely the businesses that this European facility should support.  I am proud to have supported a commitment of GBP 96 million to voluntary and social sector enterprises in the structural investment funds in the last five years, in addition to 113 community grants in my constituency in the last year alone, but this should be business funding, too. I want us to find the new social entrepreneurs in the tradition of John Bird, founder of the Big Issue newspaper for homeless people who lives in Cambridgeshire, or Andy Bradley, the Essex social entrepreneur who is helping health providers rediscover compassion. Our vote tomorrow will help find them.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Madam President, I have personally witnessed how microfinance is a truly excellent instrument. I once had personal experience in Istria with many users of such microfinances and I can say that I have seen how problems in many families can be solved in a quick, simple and objective way. Microfinance that focuses on self-employment, microfinance that targets marginalized communities or marginalized groups and vulnerable groups, all those groups that can really reach their new workplace with very little means, come up with something that will enable success in life.  That is why I strongly support this European Union instrument in the hope that it will have even more success, as I believe that this Commission really wants to solve the problems of the economic crisis we are witnessing.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: – A Uachtaráin, tá géarghá le micreamhaoiniú foráis ionas go mairfidh fiontair bheaga agus mheánmhéide. Is cnámh droma iad d’aon gheilleagar agus braitheann go leor ceantar orthu le haghaidh fostaíochta.  Tá an ráta dífhostaíochta in Éirinn agus ar fud na hEorpa i bhfad ró-ard agus, anois níos mó ná riamh, tá polasaithe forásacha ag teastáil ní hamháin chun cúnamh a thabhairt do na gnólachtaí beaga maireachtaint ach chun cabhrú leo forbairt agus fás agus chun breis fostaíochta a chruthú. Tá an iomad dúshlán acu agus iad in iomaíocht le mórcheannais atá ilnáisiúnta agus na corparáidí móra. Ní mórán tairbhe a bheith ag seasamh ar an dtaobhlíne ag béiceach. Tá saoráid micreamhaoinithe foráis ag teastáil atá cothrom agus úsáideach chun cabhrú leo siúd atá ag streachailt.  Chuir an Coimisiún agus an Chomhairle béim ar fhostaíocht, ar fhiontraíocht agus ar an ngeilleagar sóisialta, agus tá dualgas ann anois é sin a chur i bhfeidhm agus é a bheith á chur i bhfeidhm ar bhonn leanúnach.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the financial crisis has shown how important it is to have financial instruments such as Progress, in order to create new businesses and promote employment and to ensure that the unemployed, disadvantaged people and micro-enterprises have access to credit.  Microcredit is also an instrument of social policy, intended to offer a chance to those in a complicated social situation. However, the spread of Progress is still limited in the European Union. The Commission and the Member States should set up contact points to promote knowledge of this instrument among potential beneficiaries and citizens in general and to raise awareness of the existence of the instrument and the advantages it offers and the mode of access, especially in peripheral regions.  Progress should take greater account of the added value that projects can bring to regions with serious and permanent natural or demographic disadvantages, for example the regions of southern Italy, where I come from, where job creation, particularly for young people, is a priority that needs to be answered.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, our debate today demonstrates that we largely share the same position as regards the need not only to pursue the support provided under the Progress Microfinance Scheme, but also to improve its performance and coverage. Therefore, I am confident that the newly designed Employment and Social Innovation (EaSI) programme and its specific features relating to the social economy or outreach to people at risk of financial exclusion, such as migrants or refugees, will better meet the needs we have both identified. I am particularly satisfied about the excellent cooperation we have established with the EIB group so far and the strong start for the EaSI programme. In this respect, I look forward to developing further the magnitude and effectiveness of the financial support provided by the EU to more people willing to progress from being jobseekers to becoming job creators.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to thank all those who have taken part in this debate. I would also like to thank all those who have taken part in this report. As we can see, this financial instrument that we have been talking about today is very important and has also produced successes. However, we have also heard here today and not only read in the report that there is still room for improvement and that we are also pinning very high hopes on the EaSi programme. We had several hearings, one hearing in the EMPL committee and also a hearing organised by Mrs Weber of the ALDE Group. We have heard beneficiaries in these hearings. This was very interesting not only for me as rapporteur, but also very interesting for all those involved, and also very impressive in some cases, because you really saw that people who no longer have a chance to get loans in the normal market, got loans and managed very successfully with them, were able to set up companies that could hire more employees. , in some cases even able to expand, and we have seen a successful program there. In essence, however, we have also seen that with relatively little money, very, very much can be achieved. I look forward to seeing – and i think all those who have contributed to the report – see what happens in the next few years. We will follow this very closely. I would also like to thank the Commission in particular for what we have heard here today. Finally, I would like to thank you once again for the last few months. It was my first report here in this House and I was very pleased to be involved in it. I am also looking forward to working together on further reports.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 15 December 2015. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. – We support the report positively and believe that microcredit works not only in developing countries but also in Europe. However, in Europe they must be treated primarily as a social policy instrument which provides an opportunity for people in difficult social situations. To promote SMEs and innovative ideas, there are other possibilities for support. The definition of EU micro-credit needs to be reviewed and adapted to current realities. This also applies to the maximum amount of credit, which is probably not sufficient in all EU countries. All Member States should be given the possibility of mediation for the granting of microcredit to non-bank institutions. Expert assistance in the development of a business plan and the examination and monitoring of the business idea (training and guidance) should be funded under EaSI. Taking into account the improvements under EaSI and the proposals made in this report, the continuation of the Progress programme is broadly recommended.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
