text: in writing. – The European Progress Microfinance Facility is an opportunity that all Member States need to benefit from in order to build a positive effect on their local economies, boost youth employment and provide lasting jobs for disadvantaged people, immigrants, etc. Also, for the moment, the instrument is not applied in all Member States, and where it is implemented, awareness is not sufficient and does not reach potential beneficiaries. Unfortunately, in countries the percentage of rejected application projects is still too high. Very often entrepreneurs prefer to apply for expensive loans, because the bureaucracy from the moment of application to receiving the loan, and in monitoring afterwards, is too heavy. The instrument must complement and not overlap with european social fund funding. We have EUR 919 469 000 for the new programming period. Maximum efficiency, real added value and measurable results are needed – for example, monitoring the percentage of entrepreneurs realised with Progress microfinance. I recommend: clearer application procedures, more awareness, less red tape and easier access for micro-enterprises.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The next item is the report by Alessandra Mussolini, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the draft Council implementing decision approving the conclusion by the European Police Office (Europol) of the Agreement on Strategic Cooperation in the fight against serious crime and terrorism between the United Arab Emirates and Europol (10510/2015 – C8—0275/2015 – 2015/0809(CNS)) (A8—0351/2015).

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this text refers to an agreement between the European Police Office Europol and the United Arab Emirates on strategic cooperation in the fight against serious crime and terrorism.  In view of the peculiarity of the moment, it is our duty to support all efforts to prevent and combat criminal events that attack the personal and economic well-being of our citizens, just as it is essential to create the conditions for those guilty of crimes to be brought to justice.  The agreement we are debating today, which the Council has informally approved pending consultation with the European Parliament, will formally sanction cooperation between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates in the field of security and the fight against organised crime through the exchange of information on methods of crime prevention, specialist knowledge and the results of strategic analyses.  This agreement is strategic and non-operational, thus excluding implications for personal data and, as Europol has repeatedly pointed out, the United Arab Emirates is turning into a basin for economic and financial crime. It is well known that they are considered to be a country of destination for the proceeds of illegal activities, such as VAT fraud against European states, and money laundering. It is clear that more structured cooperation would strengthen Europol's coordinating role with a view to resolving in practice investigations, the outcome of which involves two or more European states.  Cross-border criminal networks can only be effectively combated through synergistic cooperation at international level. In the light of the above and taking into account the terms of the European Parliament's participation in the procedure provided for in this particular case, I have presented a report supporting the Council's decision to authorise the agreement negotiated between Europol and the United Arab Emirates on the fight against crime and terrorism.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, there is more hypocrisy and bilingualism in the fight against terrorism, especially in view of the strategic cooperation between the United Arab Emirates and Europol, because it is well known that, apart from Turkey, there are certain Arab countries that support Daesh. On 16 November, the British Guardian, the well-known newspaper, presented a document from the United States State Department revealing the jihadists' economic relations with Saudi Arabia and other Arab countries, including the United Arab Emirates. In order to tackle Daesh terrorism, the umbilical cord between terrorism and money must therefore be cut. If the Arab Emirates wants to contribute to the fight against terrorism, then it must accept, in the first instance, the thousands of refugees from Iraq and Syria that have flooded Greece and other European states. Everything else is nothing but cheap political consumption and propaganda that acts as a "fig leaf" to cover the Emirates' relations with the jihadists.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – Madam President, the United Arab Emirates is a Federal State composed of seven Emirates which have a high degree of autonomy. Two Emirates dominate the Federation. The first, which concentrates the largest oil reserves, and the second, which bases its wealth on two port areas. Both are regarded as a turntable covering up all types of illicit activities, including economic and financial crime and money laundering.  The gains resulting from these activities, such as VAT fraud, tax evasion and tax avoidance, etc., are, in turn, reinvested in the United Arab Emirates, where the protagonists of all these schemes take refuge, i.e. we once again have here the free zones and tax havens emerging as the main characters of a drama that touches Europe and allows the maintenance of all kinds of illicit activities that cover up , in the last degree, terrorism, but also fraud and tax evasion.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Madam President, interinstitutional cooperation with the countries of the Middle East and The Middle East is the basis for the common fight against terrorism and serious crime associated with it, but without a quality upgrade on this basis there is no effective stopping of this global sleaw. Namely, we must not close our eyes to the double play of some of the Gulf countries that formally cooperate with the West on the one hand, while inciting religious extremism on the other and sponsoring violence and terrorism. The time is coming when the geopolitical reasons why such a threat has so far been tolerated will not be enough to justify our cooperation with dishonest partners who openly sponsor those groups that directly threat the safety of our citizens. The Emirates nevertheless represents a good example in this region and I hope for the full implementation of this cooperation, which should serve as an example to other countries in this part of the world in the future.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission takes note of the request to the European Parliament to support the conclusion of a strategic cooperation agreement with the United Arab Emirates. According to Europol specialists, this agreement will be the first step of an enhanced cooperation aimed at tackling organised crime, in particular of a financial and economic nature. In the current circumstances, and in consideration of the current geopolitical instability in that geographical area, it is hoped that the conclusion of this agreement will bring operational benefits to the EU in its efforts to prevent and fight serious and organised crime. However, the Commission would like to comment on paragraph 4 of Parliament’s resolution. In the context of the negotiations on the Europol regulation, it has been agreed that the Commission assesses the provisions contained in the cooperation agreements between Europol and third countries allowing for the exchange of personal data. The strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and the United Arab Emirates does not concern the exchange of personal data. Therefore, the Commission believes that an assessment as foreseen in paragraph 4 of the resolution would not be appropriate.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 15 December 2015.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The next item is the report by Gabriel Mato, on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, on a new CFP: structure for technical measures and multiannual plans (2015/2092(INI)) (A8—0328/2015).

name: Gabriel MATO
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like my first words to be to thank all the contributions of my colleagues and for the cooperation of the House services in bringing this report forward. Technical measures and multiannual plans are the main instruments for achieving the objectives of the common fisheries policy, and let us not be fooled by the concept of 'technical' as if it were a secondary concept. In fact, this issue is of first-class political importance. Technical measures determine the lives of hundreds of thousands of fishermen and, therefore, it is important that we succeed in their formulation.  We believe that it is necessary to amend the existing legislation, consisting of a large number of legislative acts, in order to adapt it to the new common fisheries policy by incorporating aspects such as the prohibition of discards and regionalisation. This review should allow for simplification and reformulation of rules that have become obsolete after the reform of the CFP, as well as those that are not working or should be improved, and, of course, should serve to improve the understanding of the battery of intricate legislative texts that are in force in order to facilitate their compliance by the sectors concerned.  We have a challenge. The new regulation needs to be able to respond quickly to changes in resources and ecosystems and take into account in real time the technical development of more selective fishing gear. European legislation should support this development, not be a brake on it, as well as rely on scientifically proven foundations.  Greater dynamism must be ensured in resource management and the participation of the fisheries sector in decision-making should be ensured, as well as more rational management of fisheries through regionalization. We need, as the sector asks us, a flexible framework, capable of responding to the different circumstances and new situations that we face at all times. And I would like to draw attention to the importance of always meeting proportionality criteria to avoid insalvable socio-economic consequences. In this report we are discussing today, I propose an architecture for the new four-axis articulated regulation: three of them would cover, on the one hand, a set of common and centralised rules, specific rules for the most important sea basins and a number of specific regulations adopted by codecision; and a fourth axis, subject to regionalization, should be applied to regional standards subject to frequent changes. With regard to multiannual plans, they represent the most suitable vehicle for the adoption and implementation of specific technical measures for the different fishing areas. We must therefore ensure that they meet their objective. It is necessary for co-legislators to continue the effort to reach agreements on multiannual plans with regard to the institutional competences provided for in the Treaty and on the basis of the most recent relevant case-law. And, of course, stakeholder participation in the design and development of these plans and in all regionalization decisions must be increased.  I hope that my initiative report will kick-start for a constructive debate in which we should do everything possible to listen to the various fisheries sectors concerned and achieve a harmony between their interests and the preservation of marine resources. I hope, Commissioner, that the proposal prepared by the Commission and which we hope to know in a few months will take these principles and recommendations into account.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Madam President, congratulations to Mr Mato on his report. The amendment of the Technical Measures Regulation is necessary to adapt it to the important developments introduced by the common fisheries policy, such as the prohibition of discards. In addition, a new set of technical measures will put an end to the current regulatory dispersion situation, as the measures are currently distributed in more than thirty regulations.  It is necessary to establish a general framework of common rules for all basins through the regular codecision process, as well as to establish, through regionalization, those rules of a rather regional nature and subject to more frequent changes, thus introducing some flexibility.  As rapporteur Mato has said, the sector must also participate in the process of regulatory change. In addition, technical measures should be based on rigorous studies taking into account environmental sustainability, but also the economic and social dimension of fisheries. Mistakes from the past, such as the Commission's old proposal on the total ban on drift nets, must be avoided.  And I end by congratulating Mr. Mato again.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: – Madam President, I would like to emphasize that, as defined in this report, fisheries in Europe must follow the new Common Fisheries Policy and must accommodate the Marine Strategy Framework Directive. When we are in full discussion of fishing opportunities for next year and when we are discussing the Multiannual Plan for the Baltic, we see that the Council's option remains to torpedo the scientifically proposed limits, almost always exceeding these indications. This is a serious situation and has consequences for the sustainability of water sources in the short term and a risk, possibly irremediable, to the incomes and jobs of fishermen in the medium and long term. We need to change and accept the need to look at the safety of fish sources and not define strategic plans as if we were to live yesterday. I would like to congratulate the rapporteur Gabriel Mato on the work done. We may not fully agree with some of the details of this report, but we are in full harmony with the need to preserve the sustainability of fishermen, marine resources and ecosystems.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Madam President, adapting technical measures to the specifics of each fishing region is the correct path towards sustainable fisheries. Our struggle is common, but solutions must not be universal, but must respect all our differences and I am glad that the rapporteur has recognised this and understands this. In Europe, there are still regions where fishing is not only an industry and a big business, but a way of life that has existed for centuries and needs to be preserved. Universal solutions under the Regulation on management measures for the sustainable exploitation of fishing resources in the Mediterranean Sea that prohibited a whole range of tools in non-economic fishing have seriously undermined, for example, the social picture of Croatian islands and coasts, which is inadmissible. As we fight to right this injustice, I will be very happy to support this resolution, as its recommendations on adapting the Common Fisheries Policy to the specific needs of different regions are absolutely a step in the right direction.

name: Werner KUHN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I am very grateful to Gabriel Mato for bringing this own-initiative report to Parliament now, so that we can clearly define our position before the Commission publishes the draft technical measures and the control regulation. Many things are indeed over-regulated in the fisheries sector. This creates a great distance between the small and small-scale fishing sector, inshore fishing, but also deep-sea fishing and the European Union, and we want to reduce that. There are so many unspeakable regulations in there that, if you have a quota, you have to write down exactly on which fishing days you are actually at sea. Then there is a one-network rule, which does not work at all for small-scale vessels in small-scale fishing, and social benefits must also be paid. That is why we absolutely need this clear definition. The fisherman really only needs three or four things, which we have clearly regulated in principle for his craft. In other words, the fishing area, the quota, it needs for the particular species, it must have a mesh size, a propulsion power and a control institution, which then controls and lands its catch.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, there is no homogeneity in the European Union's Common Fisheries Policy, as technical measures are scattered across more than 30 specific regulations, recommending a complex, heterogeneous and disorganized system of provisions, which not only lack coherence, but are also often contradictory to each other. The geographical approach to technical measures clearly reflects the different treatment accorded to the Mediterranean, as the Commission, in its recent study of technical measures, did not include the Mediterranean because of its complexity. Once again we see the two-speed Europe, the Europe of the rich North and the Europe of the impoverished South.  The European Union must not separate its Common Fisheries Policy but instead adopt equal measures for all the countries of the European Union. At the same time, it must financially support the poor fishermen of my country, Greece, who are unable to cope financially, because of the unaffordable Third Memorandum imposed by the Troika on Greece, destroying the primary sector, a primary sector in which farmers have stood up against the tax policy of the Troika and the SYRIZA-ANEL Government.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, tá spéis agam san ábhar seo mar tagaim ó Éirinn iathghlas oileánach agus dar ndóigh tá a lán daoine thart ar an gcósta ag brath ar iascaireacht chun maireachtaint. Tá siad ag iascaireacht leis na cianta agus dar ndóigh deirtear liom go bhfuil a lán díobh thíos leis de bharr pholasaithe na hEorpa – n’fheadar an bhfuil sé sin fíor nó nach bhfuil sé fíor, ach is dócha go gcaithfear éisteacht leis an méid atá le rá acu.  Dá bhrí sin nuair atáimid ag déanamh leasú ar pholasaí na hEorpa maidir le hiascaireacht caithfimid éisteacht le guth na n-iascairí féin, go háirithe na hiascairí le báid bheaga agus mar sin de. Is dóigh liom go gceapann siad nach n-éisteann aon duine leo. Go háirithe, nuair a bhímid ag féachaint ar chuótaí agus mar sin de ba chóir dúinn féachaint ar shlí chun níos mó a thabhairt dóibh, bunaithe dar ndóigh ar eolaíocht ach ag an am gcéanna chun bheith féaráilte leo. Mar tá siad, mar a deirim, ag brath ar an ngairm bheatha seo agus tá an comhluadar go léir ag brath air chomh maith.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, technical measures and multiannual plans are useful tools with potential in fisheries management. Multiannual plans have, in general terms, the advantage of allowing some stability and predictability to a sector affected as few by enormous instability, but these plans should be framed in proximity management capable of involving the sector and in which Member States play a leading role. The institutional framework in force since the Treaty of Lisbon, which enshrines the management of marine living resources as an exclusive competence of the European Union, imposes centralised fisheries management far from the reality, which does not take into account the enormous diversity that characterises the sector in terms of resources, fleets, fishing gear and fisheries, making proximity management impossible. It is this proximity management that best meets the objectives of a fisheries policy: ensuring the public supply of fish, ensuring decent incomes for fishermen, promoting the development of coastal communities and doing all this by ensuring good conservation of resources.

name: João FERREIRA
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, we highly appreciate the own-initiative report on technical conservation measures prepared by Mr Mato, which provides a valuable insight into Parliament’s thinking on how the proposal for technical measures should look.  The report is very timely, because the Commission is at this moment preparing a legislative proposal for modernised technical conservation measures for the whole EU. I am happy to say the report is well in line with our own analysis, recognising regionalisation and simplification as the way forward. The new proposal is a priority for the Commission, and I can confirm that we intend to table the proposal early in 2016.  It will basically consist of a framework body of basic rules, covering all EU waters. We intend to concentrate on changing the governance model. This will allow for regionalisation, and changes to the substance will be limited to simplification by removing redundant measures and regionalising others. This is an ideal opportunity to apply a more flexible approach to achieving our objective of sustainable fisheries management.  It is also important to underline that the new proposal will not change the conservation standards that we have now: it rather enables improved conservation. On multiannual plans, again, the Commission very much agrees with the analysis in your report. These plans are a crucial element of the reformed common fisheries policy because, firstly, they are the main instrument for achieving the objective of maximum sustainable yields in an orderly fashion. Secondly, they contribute to certainty and stability for the industry. Thirdly, they are an important tool for implementing the landing obligation and regionalisation. The negotiation on the first such multiannual plan for the Baltic fisheries is finally progressing well. We have largely overcome the interinstitutional and political differences, and the Commission is hopeful that we can achieve a compromise soon. We will continue to facilitate such an agreement.  We look forward to working with Parliament on these two important issues, which are both vital parts in reaching our common goal of long—term environmentally, economically and socially sustainable fisheries.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 15 December 2015. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. – I welcome this report, as it seeks, on the one hand, to put an end to the debate on competences between the Council and the EP, and, on the other hand, to simplify and speed up the adoption of fishing quotas and technical measures and to broaden the range of scientific organisations involved in the preparation. It is clear that, in order to maintain marine fish stocks, the European Union is being forced to impose appropriate restrictions on sea fishing, as overfishing has put fish stocks at risk. Justified steps to maintain them will result in a continuous and significant reduction in the amount of marine fish fish fished.  Therefore, the common fisheries policy should pay much more attention to sustainable fish farming, i.e. aquaculture, and in particular freshwater fish farming. In Hungary we find highly developed closed-system fish farms that are productive, sustainable and contribute significantly to the survival of biodiversity. The European Union must support these economies by all means.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The next item is the one-minute speeches on matters of political importance (Rule 163).

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Commissioner, I returned this morning from Cuba, where I was on the European Union's human rights observation mission, and I can tell you, ladies and gentlemen, one thing. I have not seen so much violence against people publicly, when dissidents are being splintered right on the street on human rights day. Commissioner, I would like to say to you, and I would perhaps like to draw your attention to the fact that when we deal with dictators, which the Cuban regime undoubtedly simply is, we must not trade pate for human rights and we must not trade the economic situation for wanting human rights to be respected. Cuban dissidents have given the letter L as a sign of their resistance.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, on 5 December, Storm Desmond, an extra—tropical cyclone, hit the coast of Cumbria in the north-west of England, where my office is based. Over the next two days torrential rainfall in excess of 300 millimetres, the highest levels in recorded history, fell across the county and beyond, causing river levels to rise, drains to overflow, bridges to collapse. Thousands of homes and businesses were flooded, many for the third time in ten years. Whilst world leaders argued over a climate deal in Paris, thousands of people in my constituency were bearing the brunt of global warming. Many are now homeless climate refugees, just before Christmas. Infrastructure is damaged and local businesses are suffering. My constituents have demonstrated enormous resilience and community spirit but we are still missing significant financial support. We need David Cameron and the UK Government to act now to provide both immediate help, through accessing the EU solidarity funds, and by investing in long-term environmental solutions.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Madam President, in times of crisis, journalistic work gains further meaning, and the media and their professionalism become essential for social stability and peace. The slightest unprofessionality in such chaotic circumstances can turn into a spark that will ignite a blaze of intolerance and violence. One example is Britain's The Sun, which published an unverified story that could have seriously damaged the reputation of the Republic of Croatia. Croatia does not have the logistics to cope with a crisis of this magnitude for a long time, but for now our policemen, soldiers and citizens are more than well remediating the consequences of other people's irresponsibility and political failures.  They should be thanked for this, not falsely accused, so I hereby invite fellow MPs to join me in condemning this kind of journalistic unprofessionalism today, while it is still an exception, because already tomorrow such dangerous behavior could become the norm.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Madam President, over the last week excessive levels of rainfall – courtesy of Storm Desmond, as referred to by my colleague Mrs Ward – have also resulted in widespread flooding in Ireland. Significant damage has been done to homes, to businesses and to farmlands.  While action needs to be taken at national level, there is also a European dimension. First of all we have to assess the damage to see if there is a basis for applying the Solidarity Fund. Secondly, we need to make better use of regional funds. Indeed, former Commissioner Hahn confirmed to me over three years ago that regional funds could be used for the purpose of putting flood defences in place. Thirdly, and perhaps most urgently, is the following: time and time again we have been told in Ireland that we cannot dredge or drain any rivers, as European legislation – the Habitats Directive – will prevent it. I do not believe that this directive was ever intended to stop reasonable, workable and effective flood mitigation measures. We need to get our act together in Ireland and have one body in place overseeing, managing the issue, doing what needs to be done and doing what works.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: – Madam President, for two months 120 seiners have been tied up in Galician ports. Galicia's shipowners' association maintains a camp in front of the Galician government. They denounce that the distribution of the quota for historical rights threatens the survival of the 1 200 families who depend on these boats, endangering thousands of indirect jobs and also the future of galicia's coastal regions. The men and women of the seiners demand justice, a non-discriminatory distribution of quotas – and that they be distributed per crew member. I call on the European institutions to ensure that the Spanish government, when distributing quotas, complies with the socio-economic criteria, as set out in Article 17 of the Common Fisheries Policy, which it is not doing.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: – Madam President, Europe is at stake. Messages accumulate in that regard. First, the European Union-Turkey summit warns us of a risk of distortion of the accession process, in exchange for border guard service. Europe flees its responsibility and delegates it, closing its eyes to the validity of the values that define it.  Second, the refugee crisis. The Council, instead of organising and directing the reception of citizens, threatens the suspension of Schengen. Europe, frightened of what it does not know how to manage, is turning back twenty years.  Third, the Climate Conference. Very good news and good example of global governance, but also a clear message of demand for the European Union. Will it be able to ensure that Member States respect and fulfil their commitments? Fourth, the French regional elections. Saved at the last second, but clear announcement of more problems for France and For Europe. The only useful announcement would be the change in austerity policies, which have multiplied Euroscepticism.  And fifthly, the United Kingdom's warning of its possible departure, with the privilege of conditioning its membership of the European Union's actual resignation to continue its economic and democratic construction.  Two conclusions: the principle of subsidiarity must be reread and applied to the last consequences. More power and more responsibility for countries and regions such as Catalonia, Scotland, and Corsica. More decision-making capacity for the European Union in its federal version... (The Chairperson interrupts the speaker)

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, COP21 has ended and the great absentee from the debate is agriculture, food and the link that there is with climate policies.  The link between industrial agriculture and climate change is twofold. On the one hand, industrial food production is massive, it is based on fossil fuels; on the other hand, monocultures on 80% of the total arable land are not adaptable to climate change, making the entire food supply sector at risk.  We no longer have time to make general speeches or make small steps if we are to tackle the urgent problem of climate change, the European Union must also abandon the concept of technological neutrality and take decisive action to promote those production models of distribution and consumption that can reverse the trend by adopting agroecology practices. Problem agriculture could become part of the solution to climate change with an absorption potential of 40% of current emissions.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for You will remember November 2013, when, following the failure of the Association Agreement between Ukraine and the European Union, a bloody revolution took place on the Majdan, where people fought against corruption and for more democracy. And today – two years later – everything is much worse than it was then, and the old advisers of the old system are now the new advisors of the new system: a Mr. Martynenko, who is making millions in Vienna, in my own country, Austria, with letterbox companies, transferring gas, titanium and uranium from Kazakhstan via Ukraine to Russia, and where the Austrian authorities are already involved. , a Mr Kononenko, also with reference in Austria, against whom the authorities are investigating, a Mr Loschkin, the head of the Kiev Presidential Chancellery, where Austrian authorities are also investigating. I will not allow this to happen any more! I want the authorities in Austria, the Austrian Parliament, but also the European institutions to take action here. I will inform the European Commissioner for Neighbourhood Affairs. I want the people of Majdan not to die in vain and for this corrupt regime to be brought to life here.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: On 15 December 1989, the people of Timisoara, of all ethnicities and religions, rebelled in full unity against the nationalist Romanian dictatorship. Ceaușescu's infamous secret service Securitate tried in vain to turn them against each other: Romanians and Hungarians joined forces and gained freedom. A quarter of a century after the regime change, the past continues to haunt me: the Romanian Intelligence Service (SRI) provokes the Hungarian community in Transylvania like the former Securitate and tries to turn the Romanian majority against it. A glaring example of this is the indicted and arrested István Beke of Târgu-Mureş on suspicion of an act of terrorism. In this way, the terror case placed in the international context wants to stigmatise and criminalise the Hungarian Szekler Land, which is fighting for its autonomy rights. According to the Timisoara Manifesto (1990), equality of rights and freedom are also the right of romanian national minorities, namely Hungarians!

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the health system in Campania is in a critical condition.  Campania is in fact the last Italian region for the essential levels of assistance. Last for waiting lists, last for quality of care with the shame of the spending ceilings that until last year left thousands of citizens without assistance every year for four months. The rationing of expenditure from 2007 to 2014 produced widespread precariousness in campania public health, the lack of beds in hospitals, the merging of care centers and the closure of territorial services. We need the creation of a reliable and modern prevention system, innovative, efficient and respectful health care, easy access to care and guaranteed in conditions of uniformity.  Three days ago, the Italian Government appointed a new Commissioner for Health in Campania. I hope that the new Commissioner will use the means to apply the Available Community instruments more effectively, such as the Third European Union Health Programme, which complements, supports and adds value to Italian health policy.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – I strongly protest the visit of Turkish Prime Minister Davutoglu to Bulgaria at a time when the Republic of Turkey is openly participating in the Syrian civil war on the side of Islamist terrorist groups. I appreciate Turkey's military activity as an unacceptable violation of international law and the sovereign state borders of the Republic of Iraq and the Syrian Arab Republic. For me, it is beyond doubt that the Republic of Turkey is a major organizer of the migrant flow that floods the European continent. In this regard, I find the request of the Turkish authorities to be paid EUR 3 billion of our money in order to comply with its obligations, for extortion and racketeering.  In order to protect the European Union, of which we are also part, it must refuse the racket of Erodgan and Davutoglu, close its borders to illegal immigration, isolate Islamist Turkey, assist Islamic State and sabotage joint international efforts against jihadists.  We owe nothing to the Republic of Turkey, on the contrary – it has outstanding obligations to the descendants of The Thracian refugees in the amount of millions of dollars under the Angora Treaty she signed. I insist that the issue of the payment of these Turkish obligations be clearly and publicly put to the Bulgarian authorities. I insist that no support be expressed for the continuation of Turkey's negotiations on membership of the European Union, because there is no place in the Union and Davutoglu must understand this in Sofia. He also needs to understand that Sofia will not support the release of billions for the Islamist regime in Ankara.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: – Madam President, we live in a globalised world which, for the time being, is a convulsive world. And there are, therefore, many people who cling to paroxysm to the magical, dangerous thinking of nationalism, which did so much damage in the twentieth century in Europe and around the world.  The French regional elections have also affected us all, because nationalpopulism, led by Marine Le Pen, tricks the French, fed up with talk by political elites. And if it was just this, I wouldn't talk.  But very, very dangerous is the way in which French nationalpopulism makes a rude forgery of the history of France and Europe, generates a victimism that is false and demands a single discourse on the way of being French, of being European, with an ultrasentimental and sectarian language that points to immigrants and European institutions as the causes of the worsening lives of people.  And this is what is worrying, because it is a use that can affect the fundamental rights of all Europeans, who were born in the cradle of freedoms and fraternity.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: – A Uachtaráin, tá na stoirmeacha tar éis an t-uafás damáiste a dhéanamh ar fud na hÉireann agus ba mhaith liom tréaslú leis na seirbhísí slándála mar aon le gnáthphobal na tíre agus an obair iontach atá ar bun acu ag déileáil leis na stoirmeacha. Gan an mheitheal seo de dhaoine ag cabhrú lena chéile, bheadh cúrsaí i bhfad níos measa ar ndóigh.  Caithfear mar sin féin úsáid a bhaint as an gciste dlúthpháirtíochta maidir leis an Aontas Eorpach agus caithfidh siad tacú le daoine atá i gcruachás de dheascaibh na stoirme – daoine go bhfuil a dteaghlaigh, a gcuid feirmeacha agus gnónna scriosta – agus tá dualgas anois orainn an ciste seo a chur ar fáil láithreach d’Éirinn.  Tá an damáiste seo ag tarlú ní hamháin mar gheall ar an athrú aeráide ach mar thoradh ar dhrochphleanáil ar an gcéad dul síos; easpa cosanta in aghaidh stoirmeacha agus easpa pleanála straitéisí is cúis leis seo. Tá an t-eolas seo ag na húdaráis áitiúla le fada an lá agus tá sé mícheart go huile agus go hiomlán nach bhfuil plean réadúil curtha i bhfeidhm acu chun a chinntiú go mbeidh teorainn ar an saghas seo damáiste. Ní hamháin go scriosann sé saol daoine ach tá costas fadtéarmach ag gabháil leis. Agus níl sé maith go leor go ndeir an Taoiseach, Enda Kenny, nach tosaíocht é an t-athrú aeráide do rialtas na hÉireann. Caithfear aghaidh a thabhairt air seo.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: Madam President, as President of the European Free Alliance subgroup and on behalf of all my colleagues, I would like to express our great joy at yesterday's election victory of the coalition for peace in Corsica, which brings together nationalist and independence groups.  The recent history of Corsica has been neither easy nor quiet. France has not yet accepted, for example, that Corsican be the official language of the island. The Corsican Parliament also does not have legislative powers. These are anomalies, among others, that must stop democratically with the new mandate of Gilles Simeoni. I hope that in the decisive elections to be held in Corsica in two years' time, we will be able to confirm the magnificent shift towards sovereignism that gave the people of the island power and hope yesterday.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The Energy Union report we are debating today provides, among other things, for an extension of competence for the European Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators, or ACER for short. ACER issued a non-binding recommendation in September this year to separate the german-Austrian electricity price zone, notwithstanding the fact that such a separation would incur an additional annual cost of EUR 300 million, thereby substantially increasing the price of energy. However, this is not the only argument against this ACER recommendation.  The current price zone, which has been in place since 2002, ensures that almost 100% security of electricity supply is guaranteed at competitive prices. Similarly, cross-border electricity trade is a best priority for the internal electricity market, and the targets set in the Europe 2020 and 2030 strategy for the ambitious expansion of renewable energy are more feasible through the electricity price zone.  So: it makes no sense to separate the german-Austrian electricity price zone. On the contrary, the benefits are to be highlighted, and ACER should not act as a European superregulator, but rather act as a cooperation platform and conciliation body for national regulators.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as the representative of Romanians on the eastern border of the European Union, I would like to draw attention to the risks caused by the economic vulnerability of this region beyond which the wounds of the conflicts in Ukraine and the Republic of Moldova open up.  North-east Romania is suffering from a worrying development gap compared to the European average. Despite exceptional natural and human potential, national and European policies have demonstrated their inefficiency in harnessing local resources. That is why I believe that the European Commission's urgent focus is needed for the economic strengthening of the eastern flank of the European Union.  Today, it is not the armies, but the economic offensive, propaganda and diversion that alter the geopolitical reality. The break-up of Ukraine and the crisis in Chisinau are also possible because Brussels does not provide effective support for development and Europeanisation efforts at the right time. Give all European citizens an equal chance of living, so as not to have strategic surprises.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: – Madam President, chronic diseases are a massive social and economic burden for Europe. According to the ERS medical-scientific society, chronic diseases such as asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease kill hundreds of thousands of people every year and represent an economic burden of two hundred billion euros a year in the European Union alone.  Despite this, Member States are failing to comply with the recommendations of the European Semester on Chronic Diseases and to implement the UN policy declaration on non-communicable diseases. The implementation of all legislation relating to non-communicable diseases and the exchange of best practices must be strengthened urgently. I call on our President to urge the Council to take measures to raise public awareness and increase the implementation of all European and international obligations in the field of chronic diseases.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for Regional elections were held in Ukraine on 15 November this year. I have a report from election observers from the city of Dnipropetrovsk, which states, among other things, that election officers and other people were removed from a polling station, with the help of a document that was neither signed nor had an official stamp. Alleged election observers, dressed in white vests, influenced voters and paid up to 500 Hryvnia for the right vote, among other things. In the center of the city, militias were on the move, and other election observers were removed from polling stations, some by force. On 27 June 2014, we saw the signature of an association agreement between the European Union and Ukraine. EUR 1.8 billion in support was decided in March this year, and in July this year EUR 600 million has already been paid. I do not think it would be too much to ask for the European Union to take a closer look and see what is happening with this money and, in particular, which government is supported at this point.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – Madam President, the ECB is now the most powerful entity in the European Union, the result of a huge scam from which a neutral institution has been sought, with a purely technical and apolitical mission. We know the depth of this deception and have become accustomed to seeing the ECB imposing its policies on democratically elected governments over the years. We have become accustomed to living with this promiscuity between the ECB and the major international financial groups and in particular with this omnipresent entity named Goldman Sachs, with a sinister path in which many of the ECB's current decision-makers, including its chairman, intersect. What we have heard in recent weeks is that the ECB and its executive committee members meet regularly with representatives of large companies in the financial sector, even on the eve of the announcement of major monetary policy decisions. What information is exchanged at these meetings? Why are the rules of confidentiality not respected by ECB decision-makers? We are still waiting for answers from the ECB.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab While solidarity is one of the pillars of the Energy Union, projects such as Nord Stream continue to undermine solidarity in the European Union. We have repeatedly stressed that the Nord Stream project is a project that affects Europe's energy security. Today I would like to add that this project also poses a serious threat to the development of the ports of Szczecin and Świnoujście. The existing two Nord Stream threads are located at a depth of 16 meters, so larger vessels with a draught of more than 13.5 meters cannot reach the port of Świnoujście and Szczecin. This prevents container ships and mass carriers from calling at the port of Swinoujscie. Moreover, the implementation of the Nord Stream II project will consolidate this state of affairs and practically block the further development of the port of Szczecin and Świnoujście. I therefore call on the European Commission to assess the compatibility of the Nord Stream gas pipeline with EU law, with the European Union's energy objectives, including the principle of solidarity, and on the compatibility of this project with the planned development of the blue economy in the Baltic Sea area.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: – Madam President, Europe and the UK watched in horror as Storm Desmond hit parts of the northwest region which I represent. Across Cumbria thousands of homes and businesses have been devastated just weeks before Christmas. Emergency services across the region are working tirelessly to assist communities who have been affected by the storm, and I pay tribute to their work. They cannot do this work alone; they need support. I welcome the government’s announcement that it will give GBP 50 million for flood victims, but the truth is the government previously cut GBP 115 million from the flood defences. Therefore, I urge the UK Government to make all the necessary efforts to help the emergency services and victims of the flood. I call on the British Prime Minister to apply for EU Solidarity Funds without any delay. My fellow Labour MEPs and I have written to the government urging them to do so. The people of Cumbria must get the help they deserve to rebuild their lives after the storm.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, last week we celebrated the International Day of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. The preamble to this states clearly: ‘recognition of the inherent dignity and of the equal and inalienable rights of all members of the human family is the foundation of freedom, justice and peace in the world’. Indeed, we expect all Member States to abide by that in all their dealings, and rightly so. When there are breaches of human rights we often debate them here in Parliament, particularly on Thursdays in the urgent debates. I take part in these every week, and this week, for the first time, there will be one relating to a citizen from my own country: a young man who celebrated his 20th birthday at the weekend. Unfortunately it was his 850th night in prison in Egypt. He was caught up as a 17-year-old in the protests there a few years ago and is awaiting trial. So we hope, with the support of all Members of the House, to get a resolution to this and to get him returned to his family in Ireland.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Madam President, by the end of 2017 Britain will vote to decide whether we remain inside the largest regional economic bloc in the world or are cast adrift to an uncertain future outside the EU.  I believe that we should remain at the top table, rather than shouting from the sidelines. Why? For five reasons: North-East investment, jobs, our rights, our health and UK security. UK citizens, your rights at work are at stake in this debate: your right to paid holidays, your right to equal pay and your right not to be killed or injured at work. All these are EU-based rights delivered by your MEPs. This Tory government is devastating workers’ rights at home. Do not give them an easier ride. We need a stronger set of rights across Europe, and Labour MEPs are leading that fight for you. Vote to remain in and join our fight for better rights across Europe.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – In recent weeks, the entire Hungarian community in Romania has been baffled that the authorities have charged a small-town entrepreneur with committing a terrorist attack, who is the local leader of a far-right organisation, but only firecrackers and sparklers were found during the search. The whole truth will be revealed by the court, but in the meantime, there is a desirous hysteria going on in the Romanian media, and the target is the entire Romanian community.  The Hungarian minority, and even some Romanian publicists, feel as if they are aiming for deliberate interethnic tensions, and in the current difficult security situation in Europe, the accusation of terrorism is enough. The collective stigma of a community can make dialogue and debate impossible on the really important problems that are still little discussed in Romania. Obstruction of the right to use the mother tongue, questioning the symbols of the minority community, selective application of the Education Act or halting the process of returning Church property. There is a need for a real dialogue between the majority and minority in Romania on these issues, not media manipulation and collective stigma.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Madam President, I would like to congratulate the French on the result of the regional elections. Dear Frenchmen, I was afraid for you because the populism of the National Front is very attractive, but you voters, you mobilized to save the image of France. At the right time, the pro-European parties finally won. I am particularly pleased with the success of the Republicans, who are part of the family of the European People's Party. What I find very important is the success of the right in the regions where unemployment is highest, which corresponds to the assessment of the economic policy of the Socialists. For all of us, this is the political lesson to be learned: we must better respond to legitimate fears and needs with regard to immigration, security and economic and social problems.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I will also join in congratulating France and, say, not congratulating Maria Le Pen on how the elections turned out. Nevertheless, I will link what my colleague Šojdrová said, and that is the issue of linking cohesion policy with migration. I would like to say that for several times we have also heard from pro-European politicians from Germany, Austria, the Netherlands linking this subject to the fact that if some states do not want to participate in the problems of migration, and I do not rate it, they will be cut in cohesion contributions, cohesion policy. I consider this linking cohesion policy to the migration problem or the migration crisis to be a major problem in Europe. I do not think that we should be conditionally drawn on cohesion policy, cohesion funds, but of course we also have to show solidarity and I understand that, for example, cohesion policy could also be used precisely for the integration of migrants. Therefore, I want to warn against this.
